{{Thelema}}'''Aiwass''' /[[Template:Respell |aye-wazz]]/<sup>[[#Notes|[p] ]]</sup>is the name given to a voice that English occultist [[Aleister Crowley]] claimed to have heard on April 8, 9, and 10 in 1904. Crowley claimed that this voice, which he considered originated with a non-corporeal intelligence, dictated ''[[The Book of the Law]]'' (or ''Liber Legis'') to him.
==The dictation== According to Crowley, the first appearance of Aiwass was during the Three Days of the writing of ''Liber al vel Legis''. His first and only identification as such is in Chapter I: "Behold! it is revealed by Aiwass the minister of Hoor-paar-kraat" (AL I:7).<ref> Aleister Crowley. ''The Book of the Law''. Red Wheel Weiser Centennial edition, 2004, p. 25 </ref>
[[Heru-ra-ha|Hoor-paar-kraat]] (Egyptian: Har-par-khered) is more commonly referred to by the Greek transliteration [[Harpocrates]], meaning "Horus the Child", whom Crowley considered to be the central deity within the Thelemic cosmology (see: [[Aeon (Thelema)|Aeon of Horus]]). However, Harpocrates also represents the Higher Self, the [[Holy Guardian Angel]].<ref>{{Harv|Crowley|1996|p=29}}</ref>
Crowley described the encounter in detail in ''The Equinox of the Gods'', saying: {{bq|1=The Voice of Aiwass came apparently from over my left shoulder, from the furthest corner of the room. It seemed to echo itself in my physical heart in a very strange manner, hard to describe. I have noticed a similar phenomenon when I have been waiting for a message fraught with great hope or dread. The voice was passionately poured, as if Aiwass were alert about the time-limit ... The voice was of deep timbre, musical and expressive, its tones solemn, voluptuous, tender, fierce or aught else as suited the moods of the message. Not bass – perhaps a rich tenor or baritone. The English was free of either native or foreign accent, perfectly pure of local or caste mannerisms, thus startling and even uncanny at first hearing. I had a strong impression that the speaker was actually in the corner where he seemed to be, in a body of "fine matter," transparent as a veil of gauze, or a cloud of incense-smoke. He seemed to be a tall, dark man in his thirties, well-knit, active and strong, with the face of a savage king, and eyes veiled lest their gaze should destroy what they saw. The dress was not Arab; it suggested Assyria or Persia, but very vaguely. I took little note of it, for to me at that time Aiwass was an "angel" such as I had often seen in visions, a being purely astral.<ref>{{cite web |last=Crowley |first=Aleister|title=THE EQUINOX OF THE GODS – Chapter 7 |url=http://hermetic.com/crowley/equinox-of-the-gods/eqotg7.html |work=The Equinox |publisher=hermetic.com |accessdate=18 November 2012}}</ref>}}
In the later-written ''Liber 418'', the voice of the 8th Aethyr says "my name is called Aiwass," and "in ''The Book of the Law'' did I write the secrets of truth that are like unto a star and a snake and a sword." Crowley says this later manifestation took the form of a pyramid of light.
==Identity== Crowley went to great pains to argue that Aiwass was an objectively separate being from himself, possessing far more knowledge than he or any other human could possibly have. He wrote "no forger could have prepared so complex a set of numerical and literal puzzles".<ref>{{cite web |last=Crowley |first=Aleister |title=The Equinox of the Gods – Chapter 7 |url=http://hermetic.com/crowley/equinox-of-the-gods/eqotg7.html |work=The Equinox of the Gods |publisher=hermetic.com |accessdate=18 November 2012}}</ref> As Crowley writes in his ''Confessions'': "I was bound to admit that Aiwass had shown a knowledge of the Cabbala immeasurably superior to my own"<ref>{{Harv|Crowley|1979|loc=ch. 50}}</ref> and "We are forced to conclude that the author of ''The Book of the Law'' is an intelligence both alien and superior to myself, yet acquainted with my inmost secrets; and, most important point of all, that this intelligence is discarnate."<ref name="Crowley 1979 loc=ch. 49">{{Harv|Crowley|1979|loc=ch. 49}}</ref> Finally, this excerpt (also from ''Confessions'', ch.49):
{{bq|1=The existence of true religion presupposes that of some discarnate intelligence, whether we call him God or anything else. And this is exactly what no religion had ever proved scientifically. And this is what The Book of the Law does prove by internal evidence, altogether independent of any statement of mine. This proof is evidently the most important step in science that could possibly be made: for it opens up an entirely new avenue to knowledge. The immense superiority of this particular intelligence, AIWASS, to any other with which mankind has yet been in conscious communication is shown not merely by the character of the book itself, but by the fact of his comprehending perfectly the nature of the proof necessary to demonstrate the fact of his own existence and the conditions of that existence. And, further, having provided the proof required.<ref name="Crowley 1979 loc=ch. 49"/>}}
However, Crowley also spoke of Aiwass in symbolic terms. In ''The Law is for All'',<ref>{{Harv|Crowley|1996|pp=29–32}}</ref> he goes on at length in comparison to various other deities and spiritual concepts, but most especially to [[Foolishness|The Fool]]. For example, he writes of Aiwass: "In his absolute innocence and ignorance he is The Fool; he is the Saviour, being the Son who shall trample on the crocodiles and tigers, and avenge his father Osiris. Thus we see him as the Great Fool of Celtic legend, the Pure Fool of Act I of ''Parsifal'', and, generally speaking, the insane person whose words have always been taken for oracles."
Perhaps more importantly, Crowley later identified Aiwass as his own personal [[Holy Guardian Angel]] and more. Again from ''Equinox of the Gods'': "I now incline to believe that Aiwass is not only the God once held holy in Sumer, and mine own Guardian Angel, but also a man as I am, insofar as He uses a human body to make His magical link with Mankind, whom He loves, and that He is thus an [[Argenteum Astrum#Ipsissimus|Ipsissimus]], the Head of the [[A∴A∴]]"<ref>{{Harv|Crowley|1974|loc=ch. 7}}</ref>
Yet even while eventually identifying Aiwass as his Holy Guardian Angel, Crowley still went to even greater lengths in his later years to insist that Aiwass was an objective entity apart from himself, even going as far as to declare in no uncertain terms that the Holy Guardian Angel is not only entirely objective, but is also not to be confused with the "Higher Self," as in his final work, ''Magick Without Tears'': "The Holy Guardian Angel is not the 'Higher Self' but an Objective individual. . . . He is not, let me say with emphasis, a mere abstraction from yourself; and that is why I have insisted rather heavily that the term 'Higher Self' implies 'a damnable heresy and a dangerous delusion'. . . . If it were not so, there would be no point in ''The Sacred Magic of Abramelin the Mage''."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Magick Without Tears|last=Crowley|first=Aleister|publisher=Thelema Publications|year=1954|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref>
In ''Magick in Theory and Practice'', Aiwass is firmly identified by Crowley as "The Devil," "Satan," and "Lucifer," whose "emblem is Baphomet." This assertion is made while Crowley is discussing "The Devil." After explaining that "The Devil" does not exist, he goes on to clarify his statements by explaining that "The Devil" is in reality a label for the God of any people that one dislikes, and this fact has led to so much "confusion of thought" on the subject that Crowley prefers to "let names stand as they are, and to proclaim simply that AIWAZ, the solar-phallic-hermetic ‘Lucifer,’ is His own Holy Guardian Angel, and ‘The Devil’ SATAN or HADIT, the Supreme Soul behind RA-HOOR-KHUIT the Sun, the Lord of our particular unit of the Starry Universe. This serpent, SATAN, is not the enemy of Man, but He who made Gods of our race, knowing Good and Evil; He bade ‘Know Thyself!’ and taught Initiation. He is ‘the Devil’ of the Book of Thoth, and His emblem is BAPHOMET, the Androgyne who is the hieroglyph of arcane perfection."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Magick|last=Crowley|first=Aleister|publisher=Red Wheel/Weiser|year=1998|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref>
===Alternative views=== {{See also|The Book of the Law#Sceptical views}} A number of authors have expressed the view that Aiwass was most likely an unconscious manifestation of Crowley's personality. Occultist [[Israel Regardie]] argued for this view in his Crowley biography, ''The Eye in the Triangle'', and considered that [[The Book of the Law]] was a "colossal wish fulfillment" on Crowley's part.<ref name=Regardie>{{cite book| last = Regardie | first = Israel | title = The Eye in the Triangle: an Interpretation of Aleister Crowley | date = 1982| publisher = New Falcon Publications | pages = 473–494 | chapter = Chapter 15. The Book of the Law}}</ref> Regardie noted that in 1906 Crowley wrote: "It has struck me – in connection with reading Blake that Aiwass, etc. 'Force and Fire' is the very thing I lack. My 'conscience' is really an obstacle and a delusion, being a survival of heredity and education." Regardie argued that because Crowley felt that his Fundamentalist upbringing instilled him in an overly rigid conscience, when he rebelled against Christianity “he must have yearned for qualities and characteristics diametrically opposed to his own. In The Book of the Law the wish is fulfilled.” Charles R. Cammell, author of ''Aleister Crowley: The Man, the Mage, the Poet''<ref>[http://www.esoteric.msu.edu/VolumeV/ArtofLaw.htm The Art of the Law: Aleister Crowley’s Use of Ritual and Drama Justin Scott Van Kleeck]</ref> also wrote that The Book of the Law was "in part (but in part only) an emanation from Crowley's unconscious mind I can believe; for it bears a likeness to his own Daemonic personality."<ref name=Regardie/> Journalist Sarah Veale has also argued that Aiwass was an externalised part of Crowley's psyche and in support of this view quotes Crowley himself as saying:
{{bq|1=Ah, you realize that magick is something we do to ourselves. But it is more convenient to assume the objective existence of an angel who gives us new knowledge than to allege that our invocation has awakened a supernormal power in ourselves. (Kaczynski, 542)<ref name=Veale>{{Cite web |url=http://invocatio.wordpress.com/2011/08/08/the-morton-smith-aleister-crowley-connection-part-ii/ |title=The Morton Smith-Aleister Crowley Connection, Part II, Invocatio, a blog mostly about western esotericism, August 8, 2011 |access-date=2012-04-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114112404/http://invocatio.wordpress.com/2011/08/08/the-morton-smith-aleister-crowley-connection-part-ii/#comment-71 |archive-date=2012-11-14 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>}}
A number of authors such as Israel Regardie,<ref name=Regardie/> Sarah Veale,<ref name=Veale/> and academic Joshua Gunn<ref name=Gunn>{{cite book |last=Gunn |first=Joshua |title=Modern occult rhetoric: mass media and the drama of secrecy in the twentieth century |year=2011 |publisher=University of Alabama Press| |pages=91–92 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dtAm1e3S0CEC&pg=PA86&lpg=PA86&dq=criticism+of+the+book+of+the+law+crowley&source=bl&ots=oKY-zNKnRz&sig=1xB3kiZBteB0GoEcI1RMuTIoGU0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-NV-T4HYJqSziQfTy9T2CQ&ved=0CF0Q6AEwCTgK#v=onepage&q=criticism%20of%20the%20book%20of%20the%20law%20crowley&f=false}}</ref> have argued that the stylistic similarities between The Book of the Law and Crowley's other writings are evidence that Crowley rather than a discarnate entity was the sole source of the book.
Occultist Michael Aquino of the [[Temple of Set]] also believed on esoteric grounds that Aiwass was probably "a subjective idealization of Crowley's own personality".<ref name="Temple of Set">{{cite book |last=Aquino |first=Michael |title=The Temple of Set |edition=Draft 11 |date=May 1, 2010 |chapter=Appendix 5: ‘’The Book of the Law’’ – Commentary |page=218 |url=http://www.xeper.org/maquino/nm/TOSd11.pdf |access-date=2012-04-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120312024708/http://www.xeper.org/maquino/nm/TOSd11.pdf |archive-date=2012-03-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Aquino based this assertion on the fact that Aiwass identifies himself as "minister of Hoor-pa-kraat"(Chapter I, verse 7). In the view of the Temple of Set, Hoor-pa-kraat, also known as "Harpokrates" or Horus the Younger, is considered to be "the later Osirian corruption of the Great Horus" also known as Horus the Elder. Aquino does not believe in the objective existence of Hoor-pa-kraat, hence he considers the objective authenticity of Aiwass "doubtful" although he did consider The Book an "inspired utterance".
==Gematria==
Crowley, being the [[Qabalah|Qabalist]] that he was, labored to discover Aiwass's number within the system of [[gematria]]. Initially he believed that it was 78: "I had decided on AIVAS = 78, the number of Mezla, the influence from the highest unity, and therefore suitable enough as the title of a messenger from Him."<ref name="Crowley 1979 loc=ch. 85">{{Harv|Crowley|1979|loc=ch. 85}}</ref> After receiving a letter from a stranger, the typographer and publisher Samuel A. Jacobs (whose Golden Eagle Press published the work of [[e.e.cummings]] and others), and whose Hebrew name was Shmuel bar Aiwaz bie Yackou de Sherabad, Crowley asked the Hebrew spelling of Aiwaz. To Crowley's astonishment and delight, it was OIVZ, which equated to [[93 (Thelema)|93]], the number of [[Thelema]] itself, and "also that of the Lost Word of [[freemasonry]], which I had re-discovered".<ref>{{cite web|last=Crowley|first=Aleister|title=The Confessions of Aleister Crowley – Chapter 85|url=http://hermetic.com/crowley/confessions/chapter85.html|work=The Confessions of Aleister Crowley|publisher=Hermetic.com|accessdate=18 November 2012}}</ref> Crowley remained perplexed, though, since the spelling of the name in AL was "Aiwass" not "AIVAS", which does not add up to 93. However, when Crowley decided to use the Greek Qabalah, he discovered that
{{quote|. . . its value is 418! and this is the number of the Magical Formula of the [[Aeon (Thelema)|Aeon]]. It represents the practice of the Book as 93 does the theory. It is now evident with what inconceivable ingenuity AIWAZ has arranged his expression. He is not content to give one spelling of his name, however potent; he gives two which taken together are not merely twice as significant as either alone, but more so, in a degree which is beyond me to calculate.<ref name="Crowley 1979 loc=ch. 85"/>}}
According to [[Israel Regardie]],<ref>{{cite book |author=[[Israel Regardie]] |title=A Garden of Pomegranates |publisher=[[Llewellyn Worldwide|Llewellyn]] |year=1970 |chapter=The Literal Qabalah |page=115 }}</ref> a certain "Qabalist of tremendous knowledge" would have discovered a Hebrew spelling that enumerates to 418 were he aware that Tav is pronounced /s/ when without a ''[[dagesh]]'':
: (tav)400 + (aleph)1 + (waw)6 + (yod)10 + (aleph)1 = 418
==Notes== {{refbegin}} *[[#top|^]]The name "Aiwass" is pronounced [[Template:Respell|/aye-wazz/]].<ref>{{cite web |title= Electric Apricot spreads musical enlightenment |work= Daily Emerald |date= September 19, 2005 |url= https://www.dailyemerald.com/2005/09/19/electric-apricot-spreads-musical-enlightenment/ |accessdate= 2018-06-14 |at= paragraph 5}}</ref> {{refend}} {{reflist|30em}}
==References== *{{citation |last=Crowley |first=Aleister |authorlink=Aleister Crowley |year=1982 |title=The Book of the Law: Liber AL vel Legis |publisher=Weiser |url=http://www.hermetic.com/crowley/engccxx.html}} *{{citation |last=Crowley |first=Aleister |authorlink=Aleister Crowley |year=1979 |title=The Confessions of Aleister Crowley |publisher=Routledge & Kegan Paul |url=http://www.hermetic.com/crowley/confess/index.html}} *{{citation |last=Crowley |first=Aleister |authorlink=Aleister Crowley |year=1974 |title=Equinox of the Gods |publisher=Gordon Press|url=http://www.hermetic.com/crowley/eoftg/index.html}} *{{citation |last=Crowley |first=Aleister |authorlink=Aleister Crowley |year=1996 |title=The Law is for All |publisher=New Falcon Publications |isbn=1-56184-090-4}} *Thelemapedia. {{redirect|Jafari|the village in Iran|Jafari, Iran}} '''Al-Ja'fari''' ({{lang-ar|الجعفري}} {{lang-fa|جعفري}}) is a [[surname]] commonly associated with descendants of [[Ja'far al-Sadiq]], an important Muslim scholar and the [[Imamah (Shia)|6th Shia Imam]]. In South Asia, Persia and the Levant, those of this genealogy, also often take the honorific title of [[Sayyid]]. Descendants of Ja'far al-Sadiq can most commonly be found amongst the [[Shi'i]] of Iraq, Iran and the Indian subcontinent. Some [[Sunni]] Muslims also associate with the surname Ja’fari.
Variant transliterations include Ja'fari, Jaafari, Jafari, Jafri, Jaffrey or Jaffery
==Notable people with the surname Al-Ja’fari== === Afghanistan === *[[Azra Jafari]] (born 1978), mayor of Nili, the capital of Daykundi Province in Afghanistan
=== Britain === *[[Raza Jaffrey]] (born 1975), British actor and singer
=== India === *[[Ali Sardar Jafri]] (1913–2000), Urdu writer, poet, critic and film lyricist from India *[[Ehsan Jafri]] (1929–2002), Indian Muslim parliamentarian *[[Saeed Jaffrey]] (born 1929), Indian-born British actor *[[Madhur Jaffrey]] (born 1933), Indian actress and food writer *[[Javed Jaffrey]] (born 1963), Indian dancer *[[Syed Aminul Hasan Jafri]] (born 1955), Indian journalist and politician. *[[Maulana Syed Waheeduddin Hyder Jaffery|Waheeduddin Hyder Jaffery]] (born 1954), President Alavi Educational Society(Regd), President & Secretary Anjuman-e-Alavi Shia Imamia Ithna Ashari Akhbari(Regd)<ref>http://www.akhbari.org/waheed.htm</ref>
=== Iran === *[[Mohammad-Taqi Ja'fari]] (1923-1998), Iranian scholar, thinker, and theologian *[[Masoud Jafari Jozani]] (born 1948), Iranian film director, screenwriter and film producer *[[Davoud Danesh-Jafari]] (born 1954), Minister of Economy and Finance Affairs of Iran *[[Mohammad Ali Jafari]] (born 1957), commander of the Army of the Guardians of the Islamic Revolution in Iran *Afshin Jafari, known as [[Afshin (singer)|Afshin]] (born 1978), Iranian pop singer and songwriter *[[Hadi Jafari]] (born 1982), Iranian footballer *[[Mehran Jafari]] (born 1985), Iranian footballer *[[Ali Jafari]], Iranian computer scientist
=== Iraq === *[[Ibrahim al-Jaafari]] (born 1947), Prime Minister of Iraq
=== Pakistan === *[[Zamir Jafri]] (1916 – 1999), Pakistani poet *[[Husain Mohammad Jafri]],(born 1938) Chairman of Islamic Pakistan Study Centre, Aga Khan University of Karachi, Pakistan *[[Aqeel Jafri]] (born 1957), Pakistani writer, poet and architect *Muhammad Nawfal Aleem Jafri (born 2004)

[[File:Ari Elon.jpg|thumbnail|right|Ari Elon]] '''Ari Elon''' ([[Hebrew]]: ארי אלון) (born 1950) is an Israeli writer, a Talmud scholar and educator.
Elon was born in [[Jerusalem]] in 1950. He is the son of former [[Supreme Court of Israel|Israel Supreme Court]] Justice [[Menachem Elon]]. Elon's brothers include the late Israeli politician, MK [[Binyamin Elon|Benny Elon]], disgraced Rabbi [[Mordechai Elon]] and Be'er Sheva District Court Judge [[Joseph ("Sefi") Elon]] .
Despite his family's religious background, he became secular at a young age.<ref>[https://www.haaretz.com/weekend/magazine/because-judaism-isn-t-a-dirty-word-1.209168 Because Judaism isn't a dirty word], haaretz,1,4, 2007</ref> He taught Talmud and Midrash at [[The Hebrew University of Jerusalem]]. Elon taught at various institutions throughout Israel, including [[BINA Center for Jewish Identity and Hebrew Culture]], and served as the director of the Rabbinic Texts Program at the [[Reconstructionist Rabbinical College]] in [[Philadelphia]].
== Published works == * ''From Jerusalem to the Edge of Heaven'', Jewish Publication Society, 1996 * ''Trees, Earth, and Torah: A Tu B'Shvat Anthology'', (Editor) The Jewish Publication Society, 2000 * ''Ba el ha-ḳodesh : 36 agadot nistarot'', Yediʻot aḥaronot, 2005

The [[Bahá'í Faith]] in [[Greater Boston]], a [[combined statistical area]], has had glimpses of the religion in the 19th century arising to its first community of religionists at the turn of the century. Early newspaper accounts of events were followed by papers on the precursor [[Bábí]] religion by Dr. Rev. Austin H. Wright were noted, materials donated, and lost, and then other scholars began to write about the religion. The community began to coalesce being near to [[Green Acre]], founded by [[Sarah Farmer]], who publicly espoused the religion from 1901. From then on the institution would progressively be associated with Bahá'ís - a place where both locals and people from afar came to learn of the religion, and who officially took over controlling interest from 1913. Leaders rising to national prominence with a national level of organization soon arose after [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], then head of the religion, traveled through the area for about 40 days and across the United States for some 239 days. Most prominent were Harlan Ober, William Henry Randall, and Alfred E. Lunt, who served in events in the Boston area, Green Acre boards, and national institutions of the religion. In addition to national leaders in the religion, a number of notable individuals joined the religion and were increasingly visible - such as [[Urbain Ledoux]], [[Sadie and Marby Oglesby]], [[James Ferdinand Morton, Jr.]], [[Nancy Douglas Bowditch|Nancy Bowditch]], and [[Guy Murchie]]. The community moved from beginning to host public meetings to systematically support a presence in a Center in Boston with services and presentations on the religion as well as a racially integrated community since 1935. Starting about the 1950s and broadening into the 1960s there was wider recognition of the Bahá'ís themselves. Sometimes this took the form of noting their persecution in [[Bahá'í Faith in Morocco|Morocco]] and then [[Persecution of Bahá'ís|Iran]] and other times noting local concerts and fairs with their participation. The modern community, albeit a tiny fraction of the wider population, is present in some concentrations and thin areas throughout the greater Boston area. Over the last couple of decades it has been systematically pursuing programs of neighborhood community building activities of study circles, children's classes, junior youth groups, and devotional =Feb 5, 1846 | url = | access-date = June 10, 2017}} and then again later in June 1847.{{cite news | title =Punishment for apostasy | newspaper =Massachusetts Spy | location =Worcester, Massachusetts | page =3 | date =June 2, 1847 | url = | access-date = June 10, 2017}} In Bahá'í records this event is reported in ''[[The Dawn-Breakers]]'' following [[Quddús]]' arrival in Shiraz after the pilgrimage of the [[Báb]].{{cite book |author=Nabíl-i-Zarandí |authorlink=Nabíl-i-A`zam |origyear=1890 |year=1932 |title=The Dawn-Breakers: Nabíl's Narrative |chapter-url=http://bahai-library.com/books/dawnbreakers/chapters/8.html#146 |chapter=The Bab's stay in Shiraz after the pilgrimage; Interrogation by Husayn Khan of Mulla Sadiq |editor=Shoghi Effendi (translator) |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn=0-900125-22-5 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/nz/DB/ |pages=146–8 }} The next newspaper reference to events of this period was in November 1850,{{cite news | title =A new religious sect ... | newspaper =Christian Alliance and Family Visiter | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =3 | date =Nov 29, 1850 | url = | access-date =June 10, 2017 }} echoing newspaper articles as early as the previous July.{{cite web | url =https://bahai-library.com/1850_brief_reports | title =Early mention of Bábís in western newspapers, summer 1850 | author1=compiled by Ralph Wagner |author2=Steven Kolins | date =Sep 17, 2010 | website =Bahai-Library.com | access-date =June 10, 2017 }} ====Austin Wright==== The first "paper" on events of this period is a letter written to the [[American Oriental Society]] which was holding its meeting in Boston and the library of materials was held at the [[Boston Athenæum]].{{cite book | editor= Elizabeth Strout |author=Andrew Keogh | title =Catalogue of the library of the American oriental society, | publisher =Yale University Library | date =1930 | location =New Haven, Connecticut | pages =iii–v | url =http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001165697 | chapter = Preface | chapterurl =http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015033602007;view=1up;seq=11 }} The letter was originally published as part of the minutes of the Society in ''The Literary World'' of June 14, 1851,{{cite journal | title =American Oriental Society | journal =The Literary World | volume =8 | issue =228 | page = 470 | date =June 14, 1851 | url = https://bahai-library.com/wright_report_babis_urumiah | accessdate = Dec 11, 2017}} as an untitled entry whose first quote is "notice of a singular character, who has for some years past played a prominent part on the stage of Persian life" dated February 10, 1851 by Dr. Rev. [[Austin H. Wright]]. It is considered the first paper giving an account on Bábism, though it makes mistakes typical of the period. See also [[Josephus on Jesus]]. It was subsequently also published in a Vermont newspaper June 26, 1851,{{cite news | author =Austin H. Wright |editor =[[Daniel Pierce Thompson]] | title =A New Prophet | newspaper = Green Mountain Freeman | location =Montpelier Vermont | pages =1 | date =June 26, 1851 | url =http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84023209/1851-06-26/ed-1/seq-1.pdf | accessdate = March 12, 2015}} and a translation was published in a German newspaper. Wright, father of [[Lucy Myers Wright Mitchell]]{{cite web | author=Stephen L. Dyson | title =Lucy Wright Mitchell, 1845-1888 | work = | publisher =Classics Department, University of Buffalo | date =April 13, 2005 | url =http://www.brown.edu/Research/Breaking_Ground/bios/Mitchell_Lucy%20Wright.pdf | accessdate = March 11, 2015 }} and [[John Henry Wright]], was a medical missionary from New England to Persia among the [[Nestorianism|Nestorian Christians]].{{cite web | author=Justin Perkins | authorlink =Justin Perkins | title =The beloved physician - a sermon occasioned by the death of the Rev Austin H. Wright, M. D. | location =Oroomiah, Persia | publisher =NIH | date =February 8, 1965 | url =http://collections.nlm.nih.gov/pdf/nlm:nlmuid-56410970R-bk | accessdate = March 12, 2015 }} Wright followed up with another paper/letter "A short chapter in the history of Bâbeeism in Persia" to the Society published in May 1853.{{cite journal |author=Rev. Austin H. Wright | title =A Short Chapter in the History of Bâbeeism in Persia | journal =Proceedings of the Annual Meeting of the American Oriental Society | pages =10–11 | publisher =American Oriental Society | location =Boston, MA | date =May 18–19, 1853 | accessdate = March 24, 2015}} Donations to the Society, while mentioned in the first paper, are not listed actually being cataloged, however another donation in 1856 is noted when another set were sent.{{cite journal | title =Additions to the Library and Cabinet of the American Oriental Society, September 1855 - October 1856 | journal =Journal of the American Oriental Society | volume =5 | issue = | page = xxxvi | date =1856 | url =http://scans.library.utoronto.ca/pdf/1/27/journalofamerica05ameruoft/journalofamerica05ameruoft.pdf | accessdate = June 2, 2015}} The library of materials of the period was first kept under Charles Folsom at the Boston Athenæum until 1855, then the materials were moved to New Haven and accepted at Yale University in July. The collection was dispersed and then regathered, purged and organized in 1905 by Hanns Oertel. By 1930 the only Bábí related texts in the collection were later works that had been gathered by [[E. G. Browne]].{{cite book | editor= Elizabeth Strout | title =Catalogue of the library of the American oriental society, | publisher =Yale University Library | date =1930 | location =New Haven, Connecticut | pages =202, 205 | url =http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015033602007;view=1up;seq=218 }} Wright died in what was then called [[Urmia|Urumiah]], in [[Qajar dynasty|Qajar Persia]], January 14, 1865. ====Stephen Greenleaf Bulfinch==== Bostonian [[Stephen Greenleaf Bulfinch]] wrote about the religion following the work of Frenchman [[Ernst Renan]] who wrote '''The Origins of Christianity: The apostles''' in 1866.{{cite book|author=Ernest Renan|title=The Origins of Christianity: The apostles|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V7MLR8OBo_YC&pg=PA299|year=1866|publisher=Carleton|pages=299–301}}
see also {{cite news | title =Under "Some New Books", "vi" | newspaper =The Sun | location =New York, New York | pages =22 | date =September 11, 1898 | url =http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1898-09-11/ed-1/seq-22.pdf | accessdate = June 2, 2015}}{{cite web | title =Stephen Greenleaf Bulfinch - 1809-1870 | publisher =NetHymnal | date =Jan 18, 2013 | url =http://www.cyberhymnal.org/bio/b/u/l/bulfinch_sg.htm | accessdate = June 2, 2015 | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20121022235448/http://www.cyberhymnal.org/bio/b/u/l/bulfinch_sg.htm | archivedate=October 22, 2012}} Bulfinch had been a Unitarian minister since 1830 but resigned circa 1860 when he accepted the [[Trinity Doctrine]].{{cite web | author=Zach Reisch | title =Diary Offers a Unique Glimpse of the Civil War | website =Official Website of the Massachusetts Historical Society | date =August 11, 2011 | url =http://www.masshist.org/blog/618 | accessdate = June 1, 2015}} Across some 11 pages Bulfinch made comparisons between the Báb and Jesus mostly positive though he also calls the religion a "delusion".{{cite book | author=Stephen Greenleaf Bulfinch | authorlink =Stephen Greenleaf Bulfinch | title = Studies in the evidences of Christianity | chapter = Babism | chapterurl =https://archive.org/stream/cu31924031235546#page/n141/mode/2up | publisher =William V Spencer | date = 1869 | location = Boston, Massachusetts | pages =129–140 | url = https://archive.org/details/cu31924031235546}} He marks the court examination of the claims of the Báb like the examination of Jesus (suggesting the account may in fact have been copied), then after while continues: {{quote|In various respects, the history of Mirza Ali Mohammed, surnamed the Báb, presents startling resemblance to that of the Savior. Claiming descent from an ancient prophet king, he was yet, like Jesus, born in a lowly station; still he was regarded by his followers as the sovereign of his nation and of mankind, whose advent had been long foretold and ardently expected. After leading a life of purity, and uttering words of wisdom, he was put to death, through the hostility of his own government, but by the hands of foreign soldiers; and, before his execution, he was denied by some of his most prominent followers; nay, the very form of contumely with which they were compelled to treat him, was the same which had been used towards the Savior in the hall of the high priest. It is high honor for a teacher of wisdom thus to bear in his own history a resemblance to that of the Redeemer and we would fain believe that Mirza Ali Mohammed was worthy of the distinction. But we cannot forget that the claim was made for him, that he was "the Gate of Truth, the Imam of Islam," the subject of ancient prophecy, the worker of present miracles, and the destined possessor of universal empire ...}} ====James T. Bixby==== Though later than the Bábí period perse, Unitarian minister born, educated, and worked often in Massachusetts, [[James Thompson Bixby]] wrote about the religion in 1897{{cite journal | author=James T. Bixby | authorlink =James Thompson Bixby | title =Babism and the Bab | journal =The New World; A quarterly review of religion, ethics, and theology | volume =6 | issue =24 | pages =722–750 | date =December 1897 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=s6svAAAAYAAJ&dq=editions%3Asv5VcvGUqgcC&pg=PA722#v=onepage&q&f=false }} and made a student journal of Boston College doing so.{{cite news | title =Various new publications - In "The New World"... | newspaper =The Sacred Heart Review | volume=19 | issue =1 | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =19 | date = 1 January 1898 | url =http://newspapers.bc.edu/cgi-bin/bostonsh?a=d&d=BOSTONSH18980101-01.2.54 | accessdate = June 2, 2015}} He also later lectured on the religion in 1901 at [[Green Acre]].{{cite news | title =Conference School of Comparative Religion | newspaper = Cambridge Tribune | location =Cambridge Massachusetts | page =5 | date =11 May 1901 | url = http://cambridge.dlconsulting.com/cgi-bin/cambridge?a=d&d=Tribune19010511-01.2.45# | accessdate = June 1, 2015}} Bixby also turned his attention to the Bahá'í period. He published an article on the religion in August 1912 in the [[North American Review]],{{cite journal | author= James T. Bixby | authorlink = James Thompson Bixby | title =What is Behaism? | journal =North American Review June 1912, no 679 pp. | volume =195 | issue =679 | pages =833–846 | date =June 1912 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=xZw2AQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA832&ots=MisYpSg-Pm&pg=PA833#v=onepage&q&f=false | jstor = 25119778 | accessdate = July 11, 2015}}{{cite news | title =What is Behaism? | newspaper =The Brooklyn Daily Eagle | location =Brooklyn, New York | pages =12 | date =9 Aug 1912 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1100607/uncredited_review_of_james_bixby_from/ | accessdate = July 11, 2015}} after he had offered it to the Bahá'ís to review.{{cite news | author=Howard MacNutt | title =Interview at Hotel Ansonia, New York City, April 13, 1912 - Abdu'l-Baha, Rev. J. T. Bixby and Rev. Howard Colby Ives |volume=3 |number= 8 | newspaper =Star of the West | pages =5–8 | date =Aug 1, 1912 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=163 | accessdate = July 11, 2015 }} Objecting to it, an interview with [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] was subsequently arranged in April 1912 and published in [[Star of the West (Bahá'í magazine)|Star of the West]] in August as well. ===Bahá´í period firsts=== Though the religion was established in the United States before 1900, by then no more than a dozen Bahá'ís were in New England.The Baha'i Faith in America - Origins 1892-1900, vol 1, by Robert Stockman, 1985, pp. 4–5, 36–37, 95, 130–131, 209 Compared to the early growth in other places, and massive growth in [[Bahá'í Faith in South Carolina|South Carolina]] decades later, the region had relatively little Millennium interests - see [[Second Great Awakening|Second]] and [[Third Great Awakening]] and the [[Burned-over district]]. Nevertheless, individuals from, educated in, or lived their lives in, [[Greater Boston]] were among the first Bahá'ís of the United States. At the same time some perhaps well meaning if inaccurate reviews or even misinformed views of the Bábist/Bahá'í views were done as early as 1900.* {{cite news | title =A weird sect | newspaper =The Davenport Democrat and Leader | location =Davenport, Iowa | page =8 | date =1 Nov 1900 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/195262/babists_inc_letter_from_abdulbaha/ | accessdate =June 2, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Literary Notes | newspaper =The Saint Paul Globe | location =Saint Paul, Minnesota | page =4 | date =7 Nov 1900 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2238262/lillian_whiting_is_not_a_bahai_babist/ | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }} [[Thornton Chase]] (February 22, 1847 – September 30, 1912) was born in [[Springfield, Massachusetts]] and was a [[United States|U.S.]] businessman and writer; he was commonly recognized as the first convert to the [[Bahá'í Faith]] of [[western world|Occidental]] background. During his life he organized many Bahá'í activities in [[Chicago]] and [[Los Angeles]] and is considered a prominent Bahá'í. Nebraskan/Illinoian Albert Ross Vail attended [[Harvard Divinity School]], a center of [[Unitarianism|Unitarian]] training, for 3 years.{{cite news | title =Children flock to learn from Dr. Albert Vail/Philosophy class is unique |author= Sue Carson | newspaper =The News-Palladium | location =Benton Harbor, Michigan | page =4 | date =27 September 1963 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/777217/sept_27_1963_dr_albert/ | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }} Vail studied with [[William James]] on pragmatist philosophy.{{cite news | title = Dr Vail, Philosopher, dies at 85 | newspaper =The News-Palladium | location =Benton Harbor, Michigan | pages =12 | date =21 May 1966 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1109159/bahai_etc_dr_albert_r_vail_death/ | accessdate = June 2, 2015}} In 1906 he served as president of the Unitarian student group as well as the Harvard Divinity School Unitarian Club in his final year there.{{cite book|title=Unitarian Year Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3fwQAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA111|year=1904|publisher=American Unitarian Association|pages=100, 104, 110}}{{cite book | author=Jane C. The first known connection with Bahá'ís is when Vail's group hosted "Amir Ullah Fareed", who was listed as a student of the Medical College of the University, and who spoke on April 28, 1907.{{cite news | title =Persian medic delivers address on Bahaism | newspaper =Daily Illini | location =Urbana, Illinois | page =1 | date =1 May 1907 | url =http://idnc.library.illinois.edu/cgi-bin/illinois?a=d&d=DIL19070501.2.13 | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }} Fareed circulated some early printed prayers visible in Boston and would serve as one of `Abdu'l-Bahá's translators in 1912.{{cite web | title =Abdu'l-baha walking on the grounds of Green Acre | publisher =National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | date =2011 | url =http://centenary.bahai.us/photo/abdul-baha-walking-grounds-green-acre | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }} ==Growing community== After marrying in 1904, Khan gave a talk at Alice Ives Breed home in Cambridge, Massachusetts.{{cite news | title =To leave for Persia | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =2 Apr 1906 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/296930/bahai_ali_kuli_khan_and_family_noted/ | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }} By 1905 regular Bahá'í meetings were established in Boston whether in homes or in public venues. One early joke in the history of the religion comes from Ober about whether he was going to India or America ...
One day in the Holy Land He told Harlan Ober, an American Bahá'í, that he was to go to India. Harlan Ober did travel far and wide in the interests of the Faith, but at that particular time he did not cherish making that journey. A few days later `Abdu'l-Bahá told him to go to America. "But Master," Ober said, "I thought I was going to India." "So did Christopher Columbus," `Abdu'l-Bahá replied.{{cite book|author=Annamarie Honnold|title=Vignettes from the Life of ʻAbduʼl-Bahá|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vaTlIQAACAAJ|year=1982|publisher=G. NewVistaDesign | year = 1987 | url = http://bahai-library.com/hopson_abdulbaha_new_york | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131216001528/http://bahai-library.com/hopson_abdulbaha_new_york | archivedate = 16 December 2013 }}{{cite journal| last = Elkinton| first = Joseph| title = The Mohonk Conference on Peace and International Arbitration of 1912| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=jkErAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA379| accessdate = 27 March 2010| volume = 85| date = 30 May 1912| publisher = Edwin P. Sellew| page = 379| issue = 48| journal = The Friend; A Religious and Literary Journal }}{{cite book| authors = Free Religious Association (Boston, Mass.) Meeting| title = Proceedings at the 45th Annual meeting of the Free Religious Association| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=GC4NAAAAYAAJ| year = 1912| publisher = Adams & Co.| pages = 84–90 }}{{cite book| last = Spring| first = Agnes Wright| title = William Chapin Deming of Wyoming pioneer publisher, and state and federal official| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=trILAAAAMAAJ| year = 1944| publisher = Arthur H. Clark Company|page=161}}{{cite journal | last = Bixby | first = James T. | title = What is Behaism? | journal= The North American Review |volume=195|number= 679|date=June 1912 |pages= 833–846| jstor = 25119778}} and began
When we consider history, we find that civilization is progressing, but in this century its progress cannot be compared with that of past centuries. This is the century of light and of bounty. In the past, the unity of patriotism, the unity of nations and religions was established; but in this century, the oneness of the world of humanity is established; hence this century is greater than the past.
Harlan Ober and Grace Robarts, (who had learned of the religion from [[Lua Getsinger]],) were married July 1912 with `Abdu'l-Bahá attending.{{cite news | title = Marriage announced | newspaper = Pittsburgh Daily Post | location =Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania | page =5 | date =23 Jul 1912 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2593457/early_bahais_marry_harlan_ober_and/ | accessdate = 11 Jun 2015}}{{cite web | title =The Wedding of Grace & Harlan Ober | website =thejourneywest.org | date =July 17, 2012 | url =http://www.thejourneywest.org/2012/07/17/the-wedding-of-grace-harlan-ober/ | accessdate = June 16, 2015 | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150616162820/http://www.thejourneywest.org/2012/07/17/the-wedding-of-grace-harlan-ober/ | archivedate = June 16, 2015}} Grace served as housekeeper and hostess for `Abdu'l-Bahá during his journeys in America.{{cite book|last=Zarqáni |first=Mírzá Mahmúd-i- |title=Mahmúd's Diary Chronicling `Abdu'l-Bahá's Journey to America |url=http://bahai-library.com/zarqani_mahmuds_diary&chapter=11 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140722110120/http://bahai-library.com/zarqani_mahmuds_diary%26chapter%3D11 |archivedate=22 July 2014 |origyear=1913 |year=1998 |publisher=George Ronald |location=Oxford, UK |isbn=978-0-85398-418-4 |deadurl=yes }} ====First Boston visit==== `Abdu'l-Bahá left from New York City on the 22nd of May for [[Boston]] where he would be for four days. On the evening of his arrival he addressed a Unitarian convention then going on. There was an audience of some three thousand including hundreds of Unitarian ministers.{{cite news | title =Hear prophet from orient | newspaper =Boston Evening Transcript | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =14 | date =May 23, 1912 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=z0hfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nFQNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2948%2C4633224 | accessdate = June 28, 2015 }} On the 23rd he visited a Greek-Syrian relief agency, a special meeting at University of [[Worcester, Massachusetts]], and a party for his birthday was held during which he spoke of the importance of the Báb though he also lamented the cake, which had flags of United States, Persia, and the UK, wasn't big enough to hold flags from all countries. On the 24th he met with individuals, a talk before some Unitarians, another in Brookline, and then a talk at the home of a Bahá'í. On the 25th he met with individuals. Sometime during this visit is the incident where William Randall delivered grape juice for `Abdu'l-Bahá.{{cite web | author=Caitlin Shayda Jones| author2=Jonathan Menon | editor1=Jonathan Menon |editor2=Shahin Sobhani | title = William Henry Randall and a Glass of Grape Juice | publisher =239 Days in America; a social media documentary | date =August 29, 2012 | url =http://239days.com/2012/08/29/william-harry-randall-and-a-glass-of-grape-juice/ | accessdate = June 20, 2015 }} ====Second Boston visit==== `Abdu'l-Bahá arrived for the second time in Boston July 23 but sent most of the entourage ahead to Dublin, NH. That evening he addressed an audience at a hotel as well as a later one in the home of the Breeds. On the 24th he spoke with individual visitors and for a talk before a club. Some from the club followed him back from that talk and on return there was also a line of people waiting for him at the hotel that evening. He also spoke to the Boston Theosophical Society. On the 25th he met with individuals before he left for Dublin. ====Dublin, NH==== From July 26 to August 16 he was in Dublin. He often met with individuals and small groups or made short trips to visit nearby Baha'is and a camp for youth. He also carried on with corresponding through letter across the United States and to Europe. One evening he announced the betrothal of [[Louis G. Gregory]] and Louisa Mathew and astonished the crowd. Elders with [[ear trumpet]]s listened. Once he took his Persian entourage aside and spoke comparing feasts of kings that were brilliant but had no enthusiasm while there they ate modestly and in hard circumstances or so it seemed but everywhere there was real enthusiasm of the heart. On August 11 he was noted speaking to a local Unitarian church with answers to questions of such length and detail that it was claimed he must have memorized the answers beforehand. He compared his yearning to see the audience to the Apostles that traveled far to see people. From there he left for Green Acre August 16. ====Green Acre==== [[File:Abdul Baha in Green Acre.jpg|thumb|Photograph of Abdul-Baha visiting Green Acre, United States, in 1912]] He then went to [[Eliot, Maine]] from 16 to 23 Aug, where he stayed in [[Green Acre]]. Some five or eight hundred people were there to hear the first talk.{{cite web | author= Robert Sockett | author2=Jonathan Menon | editor1=Jonathan Menon |editor2=Shahin Sobhani | title = The Methods for Investigating Truth | publisher =239 Days in America; a social media documentary | date =August 17, 2012 | url =http://239days.com/2012/08/17/the-methods-of-investigating-reality/ | accessdate = June 20, 2015 }} The talk was about ways of knowing the truth - he disavowed individual approaches like pure reason, simple authority, individual inspiration, etc., but affirmed:
[A] statement presented to the mind accompanied by proofs which the senses can perceive to be correct, which the faculty of reason can accept, which is in accord with traditional authority and sanctioned by the promptings of the heart, can be adjudged and relied upon as perfectly correct, for it has been proved and tested by all the standards of judgment and found to be complete.
Some in the audience repudiated their former beliefs of inspiration as pure truth. At other talks members of the audience wept during his prayers or fainted. He spoke to a girls club camp group by the river on August 19. Fred Mortensen arrived August 20.{{cite web | author= Robert Sockett | author2=Jonathan Menon | editor1=Jonathan Menon |editor2=Shahin Sobhani | title = Fred Mortensen Rides the Rails | publisher =239 Days in America; a social media documentary | date =August 20, 2012 | url =http://239days.com/2012/08/20/fred-mortensen-rides-the-rails/ | accessdate = June 20, 2015 }} Mortensen had been a criminal that fled arrest - his lawyer was Bahá'í Albert Hall of Minnesota from whom he learned of the religion. Riding from Minneapolis to Cleveland he then went on to Green Acre - all by way of [[Freighthopping]]. Being introduced in a crowd he was embarrassed at his dirty appearance and then was told to sit down amid the company of people in fine dress and wait but soon `Abdu'l-Bahá returned and began to speak closely with Mortensen. His inquiry revealed how Mortisen had traveled and Mortisen felt kindness from `Abdu'l-Bahá. Mortisen had arrived on a day `Abdu'l-Baha had arranged as a feast. On the last day at Green Acre he met with individuals and left the 23rd. ====Malden, Massachusetts==== His final destination in New England was [[Malden, Massachusetts]] at the home of Maria P. Wilson, originally of Boston, where he stayed from 23 to 29 August. In Malden he spoke to various groups - a New Thought movement,{{cite web | author= Robert Sockett | author2=Jonathan Menon | editor1=Jonathan Menon |editor2=Shahin Sobhani | title = The Unmistakable and Universal Reformation | publisher =239 Days in America; a social media documentary | date =August 24, 2012 | url =http://239days.com/2012/08/24/unmistakable-and-universal-reformation/ | accessdate = June 20, 2015 }} a women's suffrage group,{{cite web | author=Caitlin Shayda Jones| author2=Jonathan Menon | editor1=Jonathan Menon |editor2=Shahin Sobhani | title = Women's Work | publisher =239 Days in America; a social media documentary | date =August 27, 2012 | url =http://239days.com/2012/08/27/womens-work/ | accessdate = June 20, 2015 }} a metaphysical thought group,{{cite web | author=Caitlin Shayda Jones| author2=Jonathan Menon | editor1=Jonathan Menon |editor2=Shahin Sobhani | title = The Responsibilities of Oneness | publisher =239 Days in America; a social media documentary | date =August 28, 2012 | url =http://239days.com/2012/08/28/the-responsibilities-of-oneness/ | accessdate = June 20, 2015 }} and a theosophical group. He also attended a marriage ceremony of Clarence Johnson and Ruby Breed, daughter of Alice Breed and sister to Florence Breed Khan. Albert Vail accompanied William H. Randall meeting `Abdu'l-Bahá there in late August.The detailed moment Vail met `Abdu'l-Bahá is unknown. `Abdu'l-Bahá arrived in Malden August 23 - {{cite web | author= Robert Sockett | author2=Jonathan Menon | editor1=Jonathan Menon |editor2=Shahin Sobhani | title = The Unmistakable and Universal Reformation | publisher =239 Days in America; a social media documentary | date =August 24, 2012 | url =http://239days.com/2012/08/24/unmistakable-and-universal-reformation/ | accessdate = June 20, 2015 }} and Vail was in Illinois by August 28 - {{cite news | title =In the afternoon ... | newspaper =The Pantagraph | location =Bloomington, Illinois | pages =10 | date =28 August 1912 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1118997/snippet_of_albert_r_vail_talk_at/ | accessdate = 6 Oct 2014}} Vail would later mark this as a pivotal point for his life{{cite book | last = Scott | first =Ethel Forbes | title =The Unitarian Church in Champaign-Urbana, 1907-1957; a brief account | publisher =The Unitarian Church in Urbana, Ill | year = 1957 | pages =Vail is mentioned extensively but some pages of priority are:p. 6, 11–13, 26 | url =https://openlibrary.org/books/OL25127899M/The_Unitarian_Church_in_Champaign-Urbana_1907-1957 }} but at first he didn't remark on it publicly. Later he said:
Six years ago I met a servant of God named Abdul Baha, so universal in mind, brilliant in utterance, so pure, so radiant with universal love, so majestic in the power of his holy spirit that I became convinced he and his equally perfect and glorious father, Baha o'llah, were God's own messengers of light and salvation to our modern world ...
`Abdu'l-Bahá then left for Montreal where he arrived near midnight on 30 August 1912. ===After affects of the visit=== A number of individuals and institutions became more prominent after `Abdu'l-Bahá's travels through the region. ====Albert Vail==== As early as January 1913 Albert Vail, then a Unitarian Minister, was visible promulgating the religion,{{cite news | title =New religions of Today | newspaper = Daily Illini | location =Urbana, Illinois | page =6 | date =12 January 1913 | url =http://idnc.library.illinois.edu/cgi-bin/illinois?a=d&d=DIL19130112.2.40 | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }} and was listed as the delegate to the "Bahai Temple Unity" national convention from the Urbana Bahá'í community.{{cite news | title =Bahai Temple Unity Convention | newspaper =Star of the West | pages =147, 149, 150, 151 | date =September 1914 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=147 | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }} He reported on developments in Urbana Illinois of study of the Bahá'í teachings and seems to quote the Writings saying: "It is remarkable to observe how the Spirit seems to catch and hold one, and the whole life seems set aflame as to the Truth. There is a mystery, a force in the Cause far above the ken of men and angels." and then spoke with an eloquence that moved and thrilled the audience. In a separate account of the convention, it was noted he was the final speaker of the meeting and that his "discourse was unique in penetrating power and beauty of utterance among all the eloquent addresses of the Convention" and that the chair had stopped reviewing the watch to limit speakers.{{cite news | title =Six annual Convention of Baha'i Temple Unity |author=Alfred Lunt | newspaper =Star of the West | page =71 | date =June 5, 1914 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=71 | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }} Both accounts lamented that the speech was not written down but one said it traced the proofs of Manifestation, noting the martyrdoms of Persia, the need of divine authority to solve human problems, and the lives of the Central Figures of the Faith. Vail was officially recognized to have joined the religion years later,{{Cite book | last = Moomen |first = Moojan | editor-last = Smith | editor-first = Peter | title = Bahá'ís in the West | publisher = Kalimat Press | year = 2004| chapter =Esslemont's Survey of the Baha'i World 1919–1920 | chapterurl = https://books.google.com/books?id=x7wyJdyE60oC&pg=PA76 | pages = 63–106 (see esp. 76–83) | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=x7wyJdyE60oC| isbn = 1-890688-11-8}} after the majority of his congregation insisted he stop promoting the religion.{{cite book |author=Jane C. Anderson | title =A history of Channing-Murray Foundation and its Red Herring | publisher =Channing-Murray Foundation | date =2000 |orig-year=1979 | pages =11–13 | url =http://www.channingmurray.org/docs/CM-History.pdf | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20131105033418/http://www.channingmurray.org/docs/CM-History.pdf | archivedate =November 5, 2013 | isbn =0-932884-25-3}} ====Green Acre and contributing to the national leadership==== {{further|Bahá'í administration|Green Acre}} In the summer of 1913 Bahá'ís felt a strength of organization to attempt to win control of the board of Green Acre.{{cite news | title =Row over "Pagan Temple" | newspaper =Arkansas City Daily Traveler | location =Arkansas City, Kansas | page =4 | date =12 Aug 1913 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1327582/arkansas_city_daily_traveler/ | accessdate = June 21, 2015 }}{{cite news | title = Plan for a new colony | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =13 Aug 1913 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/402439/1913_august_13_anti_bahist_favor_estab/ | accessdate = June 21, 2015}} Following this Kate Ives, the first Bahá'í of Boston, wrote a letter to the editor inviting Portsmouth residents to a talk on the religion.{{cite news | title =At Grange hall | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =16 Aug 1913 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/296267/bahai_meeting_about_green_acre_talk/ | accessdate = June 21, 2015}} In 1914 Alfred E. Lunt.{{cite news | title =Beha followers to attend conference (continued) | newspaper =The Oregon Daily Journal | location =Portland, Oregon | page =10 | date =15 Apr 1915 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1279331/portland_bahais_to_attend_san/ | accessdate = 11 Nov 2014}} `Abdu'l-Bahá wrote a letter about Expo thanking those that gathered.{{cite news | title =Truly I say ... |author1=`Abdu'l-Bahá|translator=Mirza Ahmad Sohrab | newspaper =Star of the West |volume=7 | number=10 | page =95 | date =September 8, 1916 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=07&page=95 | accessdate = June 19, 2015}} Following this Randall and Ober and others were visible at Green Acre.{{cite news | title =Green Acre happenings | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =5 | date =14 Aug 1915 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1253693/greenacre_meeting_includes_some_bahais/ | accessdate = 5 Nov 2014}} Sarah Farmer changed her will to bequeath Green Acre to the Bahá'ís in the event of her death and her family involuntarily committed her to a mental institution* {{cite news | title =Depositions are being taken | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =8 | date =25 Jul 1914 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/655942/1914_july_24_relatives_of_sarah_farmer/ | accessdate = July 8, 2015}} * {{cite news | title =Feb24 - Judge Hoyt ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =31 Dec 1914 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/656452/1914_dec_31_judge_hoyt_declared_sarah/ | accessdate =July 8, 2015}} - in 1915 Randall lead the idea of rescuing her executed in combination by Randal, Ledoux, and Montford Mills,{{cite journal | author= Robert P. Bowditch became more involved with costume work for theatre productions. While her life was going well she also felt "something was wanting in my existence and couldn't put a finger on ... I then began to seek for that missing link, going to most every church and attending various meetings ... (and) hearing of a meeting to be held in Boston about the Bahá'í Faith."
I'll never forget entering the large hall and seeing around me such a different type of gathering from the usual Boston crowd. Here were both rich and poor, along with every race. Many were black. I listened to a wonderful talk on the Faith by Mr. Harry Randall and was so thrilled! Afterwards I made my way straight to the table where books were being sold in order to learn more about the subject. I picked out as many as could be comfortably carried home on the streetcar, then found to my dismay that I didn't have enough money with which to pay for them! The person at the book stand told me it was all right to take them home and pay at the next meeting.
This may have been an event the Boston Bahá'í community hosted called a "World Unity Conference" as part of a series sponsored by the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States and covered in the ''Boston Evening Transcript''.{{cite web | title =Timeline of the Bahá'í Faith in Greater Boston | website =Pluralism.org | date =Jan 28, 2010 | url =http://www.pluralism.org/files/wrgb/bahai/Bahai_Timeline.pdf | format =pdf | accessdate = June 2, 2015 | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150417183719/http://pluralism.org/files/wrgb/bahai/Bahai_Timeline.pdf | archivedate = April 17, 2015 }} Randall helped organize and spoke at it.{{cite news | title = The Hour of Unity |author= Ruth Wales Randall | newspaper =Star of the West |volume=17 |number=11 | pages =339–342 | date =Feb 1927 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=17&page=322 | accessdate =June 19, 2015 }} She then credits Randall, Louise Drake Wright and her sister Mrs. George Nelson as aiding her inquiry into the religion while she read books like [[Bahá'u'lláh and the New Era]]. She officially joined the religion in 1929. Nolan | newspaper =The Crimson | location =Harvard, Massachusetts | date =November 16, 2006 | url =http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2006/11/16/go-forth-from-your-country-for/ | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }} The club was again profiled in 2007 when it was only six members and two over seas{{cite news | title =Baha'i: The New High Don't expect to find Jehovah's Witnesses preaching this religion |author= Kaoru Takasaki | newspaper =The Crimson | location =Harvard, Massachusetts | date =February 28, 2007 | url =http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2007/2/28/bahai-the-new-high-span-stylefont-weight/ | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }} though it still supported interfaith events.* {{cite news | title =Faiths Join to Give Thanks Hillel hosts Thanksgiving dinner for students of various religions | author= Jillian K. Kushner | newspaper =The Crimson | location =Harvard, Massachusetts | date =November 21, 2008 | url =http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2008/11/21/faiths-join-to-give-thanks-around/ | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Feast Celebrates Many Faiths Interfaith Council holds holiday celebration with foods from many traditions |author= Emma R. Carron | newspaper =The Crimson | location =Harvard, Massachusetts | date =December 5, 2008 | url =http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2008/12/5/feast-celebrates-many-faiths-with-tables/ | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }} [[Rainn Wilson]]'s support of [[BIHE]] related events was then noted on campus.{{cite news | title ='The Office' Actor Rainn Wilson Promotes Freedom of Education in Iran |author= Nathalie R. Miraval | newspaper =The Crimson | location =Harvard, Massachusetts | date =November 15, 2011 | url =http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2011/11/15/rainn-wilson-dwight-schrute/ | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }} From 1996 to the present the Greater Boston Bahá'í community adopted a systematic approach to grassroots community development taking root in Bahá'í communities all over the world, based around four core activities: [[Bahá'í study circle|study circles]], children's classes, junior youth groups, and devotional meetings. In 2008 the Boston Bahá'í community participated in the Stamford, Connecticut regional conferences convened by the Universal House of Justice.{{cite news | title =The Stamford Regional Conference, 13–14 December 2008 | newspaper =Bahá'í International News Service | publisher =Bahá'í International Community | date =December 2008 | url =http://news.bahai.org/community-news/regional-conferences/stamford.html | accessdate = July 4, 2015}} Boston University and MIT were among the cities of a campaign about the barriers to college education, to which [[BIHE]] was a response, in Iran in 2011-2012. A youth regional conference was also held in 2013.{{cite web | title =Boston Baha'i Youth Conference | website =BahaiTeachings.org | date =July 30, 2013 | url =http://bahaiteachings.org/youth-can-move-the-world-just-ask-uncle-kracker/boston-bahai-youth-conference | accessdate = July 6, 2015}} ===Demographics=== There is no county approaching 1% Bahá'ís in the region but there are more Bahá'ís per capita in southern New Hampshire,{{cite web | title =New Hampshire Religion Statistics | work =Homefacts Details By State | publisher =Homefacts | date =2015 | url =http://www.homefacts.com/religions/New-Hampshire.html | accessdate = April 6, 2015}} less in Massachusetts,{{cite web | title =Massachusetts Religion Statistics | work =Homefacts Details By State | publisher =Homefacts | date =2015 | url =http://www.homefacts.com/religions/Massachusetts.html | accessdate = April 6, 2015}} and least in Rhode Island.{{cite web | title =Rhode Island Religion Statistics | work =Homefacts Details By State | publisher =Homefacts | date =2015 | url =http://www.homefacts.com/religions/Rhode-Island.html | accessdate = April 6, 2015}} Within that broad pattern there are significant variations - counties where the county level per capita count of Bahá'ís is several times above or below the average. In [[Franklin County, Massachusetts]]{{cite web | title =Franklin County, Massachusetts Religion Statistics | work =Homefacts Details By State | publisher =Homefacts | date =2015 | url =http://www.homefacts.com/religions/Massachusetts/Franklin-County.html | accessdate = April 6, 2015}} and [[Hampshire County, Massachusetts]]{{cite web | title = Hampshire County, Massachusetts Religion Statistics | work =Homefacts Details By State | publisher =Homefacts | date =2015 | url =http://www.homefacts.com/religions/Massachusetts/Hampshire-County.html | accessdate = April 6, 2015}} there are 5x higher concentration of Bahá'ís than that state's average, and down to [[Bristol County, Massachusetts]]{{cite web | title = Bristol County, Massachusetts Religion Statistics | work =Homefacts Details By State | publisher =Homefacts | date =2015 | url =http://www.homefacts.com/religions/Massachusetts/Bristol-County.html | accessdate = April 6, 2015}} and [[Plymouth County, Massachusetts]]{{cite web | title = Plymouth County, Massachusetts Religion Statistics | work =Homefacts Details By State | publisher =Homefacts | date =2015 | url =http://www.homefacts.com/religions/Massachusetts/Plymouth-County.html | accessdate = April 6, 2015}} at about half the average. On one end of the greater area, for Rhode Island, per capita Bahá'í counts range from a bit above Rhode Island average in [[Newport, Rhode Island]],{{cite web | title = Newport County, Rhode Island Religion Statistics | work =Homefacts Details By State | publisher =Homefacts | date =2015 | url =http://www.homefacts.com/religions/Rhode-Island/Newport-County.html | accessdate = June 3, 2015}} to a low in [[Bristol County, Rhode Island]] at half that state's average.{{cite web | title = Bristol County, Rhode Island Religion Statistics | work =Homefacts Details By State | publisher =Homefacts | date =2015 | url =http://www.homefacts.com/religions/Rhode-Island/Bristol-County.html | accessdate = June 3, 2015}} And on the other end of the greater area in southern New Hampshire, per capita Bahá'í counts range from a high in [[Belknap County, New Hampshire]]{{cite web | title = Belknap County, New Hampshire Religion Statistics | work =Homefacts Details By State | publisher =Homefacts | date =2015 | url =http://www.homefacts.com/religions/New-Hampshire/Belknap-County.html | accessdate = June 3, 2015}} to a low of near a third of that in [[Rockingham County, New Hampshire]].{{cite web | title = Rockingham County, New Hampshire Religion Statistics | work =Homefacts Details By State | publisher =Homefacts | date =2015 | url =http://www.homefacts.com/religions/New-Hampshire/Rockingham-County.html | accessdate = June 3, 2015}} In Massachusetts, in addition to Boston, today there are Local [[Spiritual Assemblies]], the local administrative body, in [[Brookline, Massachusetts|Brookline]], [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]], [[Malden, Massachusetts|Malden]], [[Medford, Massachusetts|Medford]], [[Newton, Massachusetts|Newton]], [[Somerville, Massachusetts|Somerville]], [[Waltham, Massachusetts|Waltham]], and [[Watertown, Massachusetts|Watertown]]. ==See also== * [[Bahá'í Faith in North America]] * [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] |dependency_of = |occupants = |event = |excavations = |archaeologists = |condition = Ruins |ownership = |management = |public_access = Yes |website = |notes = }} '''Bakka''', '''Bekka''' or '''Beka''' ({{lang-ar|بكّا}}) is a [[village]] and [[municipality]] situated {{convert|85|km|mi}} east of [[Beirut]] in the [[Rashaya District]] of the [[Beqaa Governorate]] in [[Lebanon]].<ref name="KrenckerZschietzschmann1938c">{{cite book|author1=Daniel M. Krencker|author2=Willy Zschietzschmann|title=Römische Tempel in Syrien: nach Aufnahmen und Untersuchungen von Mitgliedern der Deutschen Baalbekexpedition 1901-1904, pp. 205-269 & pl, 83-116, Otto Puchstein, Bruno Schulz, Daniel Krencker|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z68QAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=17 September 2012|year=1938|publisher=W. de Gruyter & Co.}}</ref><ref name="Kaizer2008">{{cite book|author=Ted Kaizer|title=The Variety of Local Religious Life in the Near East In the Hellenistic and Roman Periods|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KgVD3WL0vAsC&pg=PA76|accessdate=20 September 2012|year=2008|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-16735-3|pages=76–}}</ref> The population of the village is [[Sunni]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Monthly - issue 91 |url=http://www.localiban.org/IMG/pdf/iiMOnthly-Municip-E91-Feb10.pdf |website=localiban |accessdate=25 December 2015 |page=7 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304111732/http://www.localiban.org/IMG/pdf/iiMOnthly-Municip-E91-Feb10.pdf |archivedate=4 March 2016 }}</ref>
==Wadi Bakka== The '''Wadi Bakka''' or '''Wadi Bekka''' runs alongside the village. The [[wadi]] was the scene of the '''Battle of Wadi Bakka''' where a [[Druze]] uprising was put down by [[Ibrahim Pasha of Egypt]] during the [[1838 Druze revolt]].<ref name="Izzeddin1993">{{cite book|author=Nejla M. Abu Izzeddin|title=The Druzes: A New Study of Their History, Faith, and Society|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BprjrZzee5EC&pg=PA218|accessdate=20 September 2012|year=1993|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-09705-6|pages=218–}}</ref>
==Roman temple== There are the ruins of a [[Roman temple]] in the village that are included in a group of [[Temples of Mount Hermon]].<ref>Tallon, Maurice., “Sanctuaires et itinéraires romains du. Chouf et du sud de la Béqa,” Mélanges de l'université Saint Joseph 43, pp. 233-50, 1967.</ref> George Taylor classified it as a [[prostylos temple]] and noted that the north and south walls remained standing and the podium floor had survived. The site has been heavily damaged by local construction of houses over the site. The temple featured an underground [[crypt]] that was accessible via one of the houses that had been built over it.<ref name="Taylor1971">{{cite book|author=George Taylor|title=The Roman temples of Lebanon: a pictorial guide. Les temples romains au Liban; guide illustré|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ii8NAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=20 September 2012|year=1971|publisher=Dar el-Machreq Publishers}}</ref>
George Taylor divided up the [[Temples of Lebanon]] into three groups, one group of [[Temples of the Beqaa Valley]] lies north of the road from [[Beirut]] to [[Damascus]]. Second, there is the group in the area south of the same road, including the [[Wadi al-Taym]] and the western flank of Mount Hermon. Third, the group in the area west of a line drawn along the ridge of Mount Lebanon. There are relatively few temples along Lebanon's coastal plain. The Temples of Mount Hermon in Taylor's second group included Bakka and [[Ain Harcha]], [[Aaiha]], [[Deir El Aachayer]], [[Dekweh]], [[Yanta (village)|Yanta]], [[Hebbariye]], [[Ain Libbaya]], [[Nebi Safa]], [[Aaqbe]], [[Khirbet El-Knese]], [[Mejdal Anjar]], [[Mdoukha]].
[[Edward Robinson (scholar)|Edward Robinson]] suggested that word ''bakka' could have derived from the later [[Arabic]] meaning of ''crowd''. Others have linked it to the [[Hebrew]] word ''bikha'' meaning ''plain''.<ref name="(viscountess)1862">{{cite book|author=Emily Anne Beaufort Smythe Strangford (viscountess)|title=Egyptian sepulchres and Syrian shrines: including some stay in the Lebanon, at Palmyra, and in western Turkey|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OMEYAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA294|accessdate=20 September 2012|year=1862|publisher=Longman, Green, Longman, and Roberts|pages=294–}}</ref>
