{{About|song by Marilyn Manson|other uses|The Beautiful People (disambiguation){{!}}Beautiful People}} {{Infobox song | name = The Beautiful People | cover = TheBeautifulPeople.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Marilyn Manson (band)|Marilyn Manson]] | album = [[Antichrist Superstar]] | released = September 22, 1996 | format = {{hlist|[[Gramophone record|10"]]|[[Gramophone record|12"]]|[[CD single|CD]]}} | recorded = [[New Orleans, Louisiana]], 1996 | studio = | venue = | genre = {{hlist|[[Alternative metal]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/post/145291-the-ten-best-alternative-metal-singles-of-the-1990s/P1/|title=The 10 Best Alternative Metal Singles of the 1990s|work=[[PopMatters]]|last=Ramirez|first=AJ|date=August 3, 2011|accessdate=November 30, 2018}}</ref>|[[industrial metal]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/marilyn-manson-mn0000825251/biography |title=Marilyn Manson {{!}} Biography & History |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |last=Ankeny |first=Jason |accessdate=December 20, 2017}}</ref>}} | length = {{duration|m=3|s=45}} | label = {{hlist|[[Nothing Records|Nothing]]|[[Interscope Records|Interscope]]}} | writer = {{hlist|[[Marilyn Manson]]|[[Twiggy Ramirez]]}} | producer = {{hlist|[[Trent Reznor]]|[[Dave Ogilvie]]|Marilyn Manson}} | prev_title = [[Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)#Marilyn Manson cover|Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)]] | prev_year = 1996 | next_title = [[Tourniquet (Marilyn Manson song)|Tourniquet]] | next_year = 1997 | misc = {{Extra album cover | header = Original cover artwork | type = single | cover = MarilynMansonBeautifulPeopleAlt.jpg | border = | alt = | caption = }} }}
"'''The Beautiful People'''" is a song by American rock band [[Marilyn Manson (band)|Marilyn Manson]]. It was released as the lead single from the band's second [[studio album]], ''[[Antichrist Superstar]]'' in September 1996. Classified as [[alternative metal]], the song was written by frontman [[Marilyn Manson]] and [[Jeordie White|Twiggy Ramirez]], and was produced by [[Trent Reznor]], [[Dave Ogilvie]] and Manson.
The title of the song comes from Marilyn Bender's 1967 book ''The Beautiful People'', about the lifestyles of the [[jet set]]<ref name="howiwrote"/> In the context of the album's concept, the song refers to the privileged [[Social class|class]] of [[elites]] whom the titular character, a [[Right-wing populism|populist]] [[demagogue]] called ''Antichrist Superstar'', fulminate against. Lyrically, it discusses what Manson refers to as "the culture of beauty".<ref name="howiwrote">Manson, Marilyn. "''How I Wrote "The Beautiful People''". May 2005, ''Kerrang!'', reported by [http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=37436 Blabbermouth.net] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070313170007/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=37436 |date=March 13, 2007 }}; last accessed September 24, 2006.</ref>
The single peaked at number 26 on the [[Modern Rock Tracks chart]] and remains known as one of Marilyn Manson's most famous and most successful original songs; in a 2004 review, Richard Banks of the BBC called the track "still the most impressive"<ref>Richard Banks, "Rock & Alt Review", 2004, at [https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/rockandalt/reviews/marilynmanson_bestof.shtml BBC.co.uk]; last accessed September 15, 2006.</ref> in the band's catalogue, and in 2006 it was ranked at number 28 on VH1's 40 Greatest Metal Songs.<ref>''"VH1 40 Greatest Metal Songs"'', May 1–4, 2006, ''VH1'' Channel, reported by [http://www.vh1.com/shows/dyn/the_greatest/103446/episode_this_list.jhtml VH1.com]; last accessed September 10, 2006.</ref>
==Song information==
===Origins=== "The Beautiful People" was written in 1994, with lyrics by Marilyn Manson and music by Twiggy Ramirez. The original demo version was written in a hotel room while on tour, and recorded to [[multitrack recording|four-track]] by Manson, Ramirez, and drummer [[Ginger Fish]]. Manson recalled to ''Kerrang!'' magazine in May 2005: "It was somewhere in [[Southern United States|the South]], which is ironic. I remember playing the drum beat on the floor and then having my drummer duplicate that on the drum machine. It happened in one day pretty much".<ref name="howiwrote a">{{Cite magazine|last=Manson|first=Marilyn|date=28 May 2005|title=How I Wrote... ''The Beautiful People''|format=transcription|url=http://www.providermodule.com/media/?v=i/2005/kerrang_bp|magazine=[[Kerrang!]]|issue=1058|access-date=11 May 2018}}</ref>
The title of the song comes from Marilyn Bender's 1967 book ''The Beautiful People'',<ref name="howiwrote"/> which exposed the world of scandal within the "jet-set" lifestyle of the 1960s, and the culture of beauty as it pertained to fashion and politics.<ref name="howiwrote"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/donotmigrate/3670958/The-book-that-started-the-madness.html|date=2008-02-03|df=mdy-all|accessdate=2017-06-18|title=The book that started the madness|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|author=Steven Daly}}</ref>
===Composition and lyrical content=== {{Listen |filename=Marilyn Manson - The Beautiful People.ogg|format=[[Ogg]] |title="The Beautiful People"|description=A sample of "The Beautiful People"}}
The song is preceded with a few seconds of [[backmasking|backwards-guitar]] feedback and electronic noise. It includes a heavily distorted spoken [[sampling (music)|sample]] by [[Charles "Tex" Watson|Tex Watson]], declaring "[We would] swoop down on the town. . . [and] kill everyone that wasn't beautiful".<ref name="lexicon">D. Damon, ''The Beautiful People''. Retrieved from [http://www.resnet.trinity.edu/ddamon/hierophant/lexicon/acs-2.htm ''The Marilyn Manson Lexicon'' (section)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070223051601/http://www.resnet.trinity.edu/ddamon/hierophant/lexicon/acs-2.htm |date=February 23, 2007 }}, last accessed October 11, 2006.</ref>
The song is written in [[drop D tuning]], and is built primarily out of [[power chords]] based on the notes of a [[diminished triad]]. It also incorporates extensive use of [[Guitar effects#Distortion-related effects|guitar distortion]], and the use of [[palm muting]] creates a highly rhythmic, driving style amplified by a heavy [[percussion instrument|percussion]] track. The song's characteristic element is its repetitive drum beat: a five-beat [[common time]] pattern played on [[floor tom]]s, with a [[swung note|shuffle note]] each measure creating a triplet feel.{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}}
[[Sean Beavan]], who mixed and co-produced ''Antichrist Superstar'', is credited with "descending horn guitar" on the track. Beavan can be heard playing a repeated descending [[figure (music)|figure]] with a [[brass instrument]]-like sound using a [[guitar synthesizer]].
Lyrically, it is entwined with the ''Antichrist Superstar'' album's overarching theme, a semi-narrative examination of the [[Friedrich Nietzsche|Nietzschean]] [[Übermensch]].<ref name="cmj">Marilyn Manson (interview). ''College Music Journal'', October, 1997.</ref> Within this context, "The Beautiful People" deals explicitly with the destructive manifestation of the Will to Power ("There's no time to discriminate / hate every [[motherfucker]] that's in your way"), while also exploring Nietzsche's view of [[master-slave morality]] ("It's not your fault that you're always wrong / The weak ones are there to justify the strong"), particularly the concept's connection with [[Social Darwinism]] and its relation to various political and economic systems such as [[capitalism]] and [[fascism]] ("Capitalism has made it this way/Old-fashioned fascism will take it away").
===Notable performances=== "The Beautiful People" was performed sporadically during the 1995–1996 [[Smells Like Children Tour]], frequently in abbreviated form as part of the ''[[Portrait of an American Family]]'' song "My Monkey". It was "officially" premiered on October 3, 1996, at the State Theatre in [[Kalamazoo]] – the second show of the band's [[Dead to the World (tour)|Dead to the World]] Tour.{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}}
On September 4, 1997, Marilyn Manson performed the song as the grand finale of the [[MTV Video Music Awards]]. Preceded by a marching band playing "[[Hail to the Chief]]", Manson entered the stage flanked by mock United States Secret Service agents and, from a microphone-covered podium, delivered a speech<ref name="MTVVideo">''MTV Video Music Awards'', MTV (television broadcast). Originally broadcast September 4, 1997.</ref> to the audience:
{{quote|My fellow Americans:
We will no longer be oppressed by the fascism of Christianity! And we will no longer be oppressed by the fascism of beauty. As I see you all sittin' out there trying your hardest not to be ugly, trying your hardest not to fit in, trying your hardest to earn your way into Heaven, but let me ask you: Do you want to be in a place that's filled with a bunch of ''assholes''?}}
Manson then threw off his costume, revealing "a leather corset, leather G-string and fishnet stockings", and the band delivered a performance of "The Beautiful People" that ''Rolling Stone'' called "riveting",<ref>''"Virtual Inanity"'', October 1997, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' № 748, reported by [https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5924661/virtual_inanity RollingStone.com]; last accessed September 10, 2006.</ref> in spite of the magazine's extremely negative review of the program as a whole. As the show closed, host [[Chris Rock]] teasingly yelled for the audience to "Run to church right now! Get your asses to church, or you're going to Hell!".<ref name="MTVVideo"/>
Marilyn Manson and Twiggy Ramirez joined [[The Smashing Pumpkins]] at Mountain View, California's [[Shoreline Amphitheatre]] for an acoustic performance of "The Beautiful People" during the venue's annual [[Bridge School Benefit]] on October 18, 1997.<ref>Neil Strauss, "POP REVIEW: Neil Young and Friends Gather to Have Fun For a Serious Purpose", October 20, 1997, ''The New York Times'', reported by [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A03E0DC1F3FF933A15753C1A961958260 NYTimes.com]; last accessed September 10, 2006</ref> [[Nine Inch Nails]] also performed "The Beautiful People", with frontman [[Trent Reznor]] on bass guitar and Marilyn Manson on lead vocals, on May 9, 2000 at [[Madison Square Garden]]. Manson had been a surprise guest at the concert, appearing unannounced on stage during Nine Inch Nails' "[[Starfuckers, Inc.]]"; this performance was filmed and released as a bonus feature on ''[[And All That Could Have Been]]'' in 2002.<ref>Richard Skanse, ''"Manson Joins NIN Onstage in NYC"'', May 10, 2000, at [https://www.rollingstone.com/artists/marilynmanson/articles/story/5925826/manson_joins_nin_onstage_in_nyc RollingStone.com]; last accessed September 10, 2006.</ref> At the 2012 [[Echo (music award)|Echo Awards]], [[Rammstein]] performed the song, with Marilyn Manson standing in for lead singer [[Till Lindemann]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mahmoud |first1=Von Karim |last2=Peters |first2=Bernd |last3=Henseke |first3=Stefon |last4=Kampe |first4=Sina |url=http://www.berliner-kurier.de/kultur-leute/echo-2012-berlin-marilyn-manson-rammstein-schoeneberger-mueller,7169134,11959656.html |title=Oldie-Alarm beim Echo Innige Zungenküsse und alte Männer(freundschaften) |work=[[Berliner Kurier]] |publisher=Berliner Verlag GmbH |date=2012-03-22|accessdate=2018-04-30}}</ref> On October 31, 2014 in a special setup on [[Halloween|Halloween night]], Manson performed the song with [[Johnny Depp]] on guitar and [[Watkin Tudor Jones|Ninja]] (from [[Die Antwoord]]) as a background vocalist, in the club [[Roxy Theatre (West Hollywood)|Roxy]] in [[West Hollywood]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Young |first=Alex |url=https://consequenceofsound.net/2014/11/marilyn-manson-performs-the-beautiful-people-with-johnny-depp-and-die-antwoord-for-some-reason-watch/ |title=Marilyn Manson performs "The Beautiful People" with Johnny Depp and Die Antwoord, for some reason — watch |work=[[Consequence of Sound]] |publisher=Consequence Holdings, LLC |date=2014-11-02|accessdate=2018-04-30}}</ref>
In live performances, Manson frequently incorporates the lyric "How does it feel to be one of the beautiful people?" from [[The Beatles]]' "[[Baby, You're a Rich Man]]" into the song, either shouted over its instrumental break or as a lead-in to the introductory drums.<ref>Track 2 on the UK CD Single 2 for "[[The Dope Show]]" [[The Dope Show]]</ref>
===Versions and releases===
In addition to the version on the ''Antichrist Superstar'' album and the version on the single (which differ only in the length of the introductory noise) a radio edit also exists, which removes the profanity. The phrase "hate every motherfucker" has been replaced by the alternate lyric "hate every other hater", and the word "shit" has been excised. This radio edit is the version used in the music video for "The Beautiful People".{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}}
Three official remixes of "The Beautiful People" have been released. The first, "The Horrible People", was created by [[Danny Saber]] and appears on the 1997 ''[[Remix & Repent]]'' EP; the remix features a fast-tempo [[drum n bass]] backing track, and accents the original song's [[Swing (genre)|swing jazz]]-inflected rhythm with brass and piano samples. [[J. G. Thirlwell]]'s "The Not-So-Beautiful People" is a straight [[industrial music|industrial]] reworking of the track, with rhythmic vocal samples and churning, [[audio filter|filtered]] [[synthesizer]]s. It was used as the opening theme for ''[[WWE Raw|WWF RAW is WAR]]'' for only a few weeks in March 1997. Later an edited version of the song was used as the opening theme for ''[[WWE SmackDown|WWE SmackDown!]]'' from 2001 to 2003, and a remix of it was included on ''[[WWF Forceable Entry]]'' and a 10-inch picture disc single of the song.
Marilyn Manson's 2004 greatest hits compilation, ''[[Lest We Forget: The Best Of|Lest We Forget]]'', contains a slightly reworked version of the track. The longer introduction from the single version has been restored, and certain musical elements (most notably, an organ-like sound not noticeable in the previously released versions) have been made more pronounced.
In 1997, [[MTV News]] reported that Manson had expressed interest in collaborating with [[Snoop Dogg]] to produce a [[rapping|rap]] version of "The Beautiful People".{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} It is unknown if the collaboration ever actually occurred, although in his September 4, 1997 keynote address at the [[College Music Journal|CMJ]] Music Marathon, the singer referred to the project as "something I would still love to do"<ref>Manson, Marilyn. Keynote address, CMJ Music Marathon, September 4, 1997 [speech]. As reported by [http://www.spookhouse.net/angelynx/manson/mmcmj.html spookhouse.net], last accessed September 22, 2006.</ref> and blamed the hectic touring schedules of both his own band and the rapper for the delay.
The song has been made available as [[downloadable content]] for ''[[Guitar Hero 5]]'' and is included on the ''[[Rock Band 3]]'' soundtrack.
==Music video== [[File:54beautiful people.jpg|left|thumb|Manson in the music video's "dental device" costume]] [[Floria Sigismondi]] directed what has been described as "the creepiest of creepy videos"<ref>Lance Teegarden, PopMatters (review of ''Lest We Forget''), January 5, 2005, reported by [http://www.popmatters.com/music/reviews/m/mansonmarilyn-lestwe.shtml PopMatters.com] (review of ''Lest We Forget''). Last accessed September 15, 2006.</ref> for "The Beautiful People". The clip, filmed in the then abandoned [[Distillery District|Gooderham and Worts]] distillery in Toronto, Canada,<ref>Carol Vernallis, ''Experiencing Music Video'', Columbia University Press, 2004. {{ISBN|0-231-11799-X}}</ref> depicts the band performing the song in a classroom-like area decorated with medical [[prosthesis|prostheses]] and laboratory equipment. Intercut with these performance clips are scenes of lead singer Marilyn Manson in a long gown-like costume and aviator goggles, wearing stilts and prosthetic makeup which make him appear bald and grotesquely tall; after being placed in this costume by similarly attired attendants, he appears to a cheering crowd through a window in a scene reminiscent of a fascist rally, and later stands in the center of a circle while people march around him giving the [[Hitler salute]]. Other [[fast cutting|fast cut]] scenes include extreme close-ups of crawling earthworms, mannequin heads and hands, and the boots of people marching; and shots of the individual band members bizarrely costumed, including Manson in back and neck braces, a leather aviator cap and an orthodontic cheek retractor, exposing metallic teeth.
The video premiered on [[MTV]] on September 22, 1996 and was nominated for two [[1997 MTV Video Music Awards]]: Best Rock Video and Best Special Effects.<ref name="1997 MTV Video Music Awards">{{cite web|url=http://www.rockonthenet.com/archive/1997/mtvvmas.htm |title= 1997 MTV Video Music Awards |publisher=Rock On The Net |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref> {{Clear}}
==Reception== The single was generally praised on its release. [[AllMusic|AllMusic's]] [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] highly praised the song, stating that "With its mock menace and pummeling metal triplets, it was the first Manson song with an oversized hook -- the kind of song that even the group's detractors couldn't get out of their heads".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/beautiful-people-mw0000916310 |title=Beautiful People- Marilyn Manson |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |website=AllMusic |access-date=October 7, 2018}}</ref> In its 1996 review of ''Antichrist Superstar'', ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine described "The Beautiful People" as "suspense-filled", with "a zombielike, repetitive quality [and] ghostly electronic sounds. . .", adding that in his vocal delivery, "Manson hisses his lines, punctuating certain words with a shrill, insane pitch, others with a retching scream".<ref>Lorraine Ali, ''"Antichrist Superstar"'' (starred review) , October 29, 1996, ''Rolling Stone'' № 748, reported by [https://www.rollingstone.com/artists/870/albums/album/306030 RollingStone.com]; last accessed September 10, 2006.</ref>
In the United States, the single managed to reach number 29 on the ''Billboard'' [[Mainstream Rock Tracks]] chart and number 26 on the [[Modern Rock Tracks]] chart.<ref>''Billboard''. As reported by [{{BillboardURLbyName|artist=marilyn manson|chart=all}} Billboard.com]. Last accessed November 8, 2006.</ref> In the UK, it reached number 18 on the [[UK Singles Chart]], peaking on June 7, 1997.<ref>UK Singles Chart. As reported by [http://www.zobbel.de/cluk/CLUK_M1.HTM Chart Log U.K.]. Last accessed November 8, 2006.</ref> In Sweden, it was certified gold.<ref name="swecertification">{{cite web|url=http://www.ifpi.se/wp/wp-content/uploads/guld-platina-1987-1998.pdf |title=Guld & Platina |publisher=IFPI Switzerland |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616145338/http://www.ifpi.se/wp/wp-content/uploads/guld-platina-1987-1998.pdf |archivedate=2011-06-16 |df= }}</ref> Although the single only peaked at number 42 on the Australian [[ARIA Charts|ARIA]] singles chart,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://australian-charts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Marilyn+Manson&titel=The+Beautiful+People&cat=s|title=australian-charts.com > Marilyn Manson - The Beautiful People (song)|publisher=Hung Medien|accessdate=October 13, 2015}}</ref> it spent 56 weeks in the top 100<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151013094652/http://i.imgur.com/n6Rv4rh.jpg|title=The ARIA Australian Top 100 Singles Chart > Week Ending 22 Feb 1998|url=http://i.imgur.com/n6Rv4rh.jpg|publisher=[[Imgur]]|archivedate=October 13, 2015|accessdate=October 13, 2015}}</ref> and became the 89th highest-selling single of 1997 in Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://i.imgur.com/jPE8T28.jpg|title=The ARIA Australian Top 100 Singles 1997|publisher=The Australian Record Industry Association Ltd.|accessdate=February 2, 2016}}</ref>
===Accolades===
According to Acclaimedmusic.net "The Beautiful People" is the 21st best song of 1996, the 349th greatest song released during the 1990s and the 2,451st greatest of all-time.<ref name="acclaimedmusic.net">{{cite web |url=http://acclaimedmusic.net/Current/Marilyn%20Manson.htm |title=Marilyn Manson Artist Rank |publisher=Acclaimedmusic.net |accessdate=2010-11-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170611030320/http://www.acclaimedmusic.net/Current/Marilyn%20Manson.htm |archivedate=2017-06-11 |df= }}</ref> In 2002, ''[[Kerrang!]]'' ranked "The Beautiful People" 5th in their ''100 Greatest Singles of All Time''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://acclaimedmusic.net/Current/kerrang.htm |title=''Kerrang!'' 100 Greatest Singles of All Time |publisher=''[[Kerrang!]]'' |accessdate=2011-03-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706141343/http://www.acclaimedmusic.net/Current/kerrang.htm |archivedate=2011-07-06 |df= }}</ref> In 2003, ''[[Q (magazine)|Q]]'' ranked "The Beautiful People" 192nd in their ''The 1001 Best Songs Ever''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.muzieklijstjes.nl/Q1001bestsongsever.htm |title=''Q'' The 1001 Best Songs Ever|publisher=''[[Q (magazine)|Q]]'' |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref> ''[[Q (magazine)|Q]]'' also included "The Beautiful People" under the Metal Tracks category of their ''Ultimate Music Collection'' in 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rocklistmusic.co.uk/qcollection.htm |title=The ''Q'' Ultimate Music Collection|publisher=''[[Q (magazine)|Q]]'' |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref> The music video for the single would be nominated in three categories at the [[1997 MTV Video Music Awards]] namely, ''[[1997 MTV Video Music Awards#Best Rock Video|Best Rock Video]]'', ''[[1997 MTV Video Music Awards#Best Art Direction in a Video|Best Art Direction]]'' and ''[[1997 MTV Video Music Awards#Best Special Effects in a Video|Best Special Effects]]''.<ref name="1997 MTV Video Music Awards"/>
In 2011, Both the original version and the Scala and Kolacny cover would be used as the theme music for the "7" Scarezone at [[Universal Orlando]]'s [[Halloween Horror Nights]] 21 Event {{Clear}}
==Cover versions== The song has been covered by various artists, including the jazz trumpeter [[Lester Bowie]], on his Brass Fantasy's 1999 ''[[The Odyssey Of Funk & Popular Music|Odyssey of Funk & Popular Music, Volume 1]]''; [[metalcore]] band [[Eighteen Visions]], on the 2006 compilation ''[[Punk Goes 90s]]''; the [[Scala & Kolacny Brothers]] girls' choir on their 2007 album ''One Winged Angel''; and [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] band [[Soulfly]] on ''[[Higher Voltage!: Another Brief History of Rock]]'' and a special edition of their album ''[[Conquer (album)|Conquer]]''.<ref>''Allmusic'', available at [http://www.allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=17:132259 allmusic.com] . Last accessed October 11, 2006. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
Samples from "The Beautiful People" have been used in two songs of the same title, one by rapper [[Apathy (rapper)|Apathy]], one by [[Christina Aguilera]] for the [[Burlesque (2010 musical film)|''Burlesque'']] [[Burlesque (soundtrack)|soundtrack]]. [[Pop punk]] singer [[Avril Lavigne]] sang the song in a medley with her own song "[[Bad Girl (Avril Lavigne song)|Bad Girl]]" (which features guest vocals from Manson) during [[The Avril Lavigne Tour]] in 2014.

{{About|the Jewish left-progressive magazine|the French philosophical journal|Tiqqun}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox magazine | image_file = Tik0701.jpg | image_size = <!-- 220px (the default if no size is stated) --> | image_alt = | image_caption = January/February 2007 issue | editor = [[Michael Lerner (rabbi)|Michael Lerner]] | editor_title = | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | frequency = quarterly | circulation = 18,000<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejewishweek.com/news/new_york/liberal_lion_autumn|title=A Liberal Lion In Autumn|website=Jewish Week|author=Jonathan Mark|date=March 14, 2011|accessdate=October 6, 2016}}</ref> | category = | company = | publisher = [[Duke University Press]] | founded = {{Start date|1986|month}} | country = United States | based = [[Berkeley, California]] | language = | website = {{URL|http://www.tikkun.org}} | issn = 0887-9982 }} '''''Tikkun''''' is a quarterly [[interfaith]] Jewish [[Left-wing politics|left]]-[[Progressivism|progressive]] magazine and website, published in the [[United States]], that analyzes [[Culture of the United States|American]] and [[Israeli culture]], politics, religion, and history in the [[English language]]. The magazine has consistently published the work of [[Israelis|Israeli]] and [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] left-wing intellectuals, but also included book and music reviews, personal essays, and poetry. In 2006 and 2011, the magazine was awarded the ''Independent Press Award for Best Spiritual Coverage'' by ''[[Utne Reader]]''<ref>{{cite journal|title= Spiritual Coverage: Tikkun |journal=Utne Reader|date= January–February 2007 |accessdate=March 4, 2016|url= http://www.utne.com/issues/2006_139/features/12371-1.html |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080907065256/http://www.utne.com/issues/2006_139/features/12371-1.html |archivedate=September 7, 2008|quote= In November, Rabbi Michael Lerner's erudite rejoinder to the religious right released ''Tikkun Reader: Twentieth Anniversary'' (Rowman & Littlefield) to showcase memorable essays from the bimonthly magazine's all-star cast of contributors}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title= Winners of the 2011 Utne Independent Press Awards |journal=Utne Reader|date= April 12, 2011 |accessdate=March 4, 2016|url= http://www.utne.com/Utne-Independent-Press-Award-Winners-2011.aspx|quote= Illuminated by the Jewish faith but accessible to all, Tikkun aims to 'mend, repair and transform the world'}}</ref> for its analysis of the inability of many progressives to understand people's yearning for faith, and the American [[fundamentalist]]s' political influence on the international conflict among religious [[zealots]]. The magazine was founded in 1986<ref>{{cite news|author=Joseph Berger|title=New Liberal Jewish Magazine Aims Fire at Commentary and Stirs Internal Protests|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/10/21/us/new-liberal-jewish-magazine-aims-fire-at-commentary-and-stirs-internal-protests.html|accessdate=February 10, 2017|work=The New York Times|date=December 21, 1986}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Steve Black|title=Life spans of Library Journal's “Best Magazines of the Year”|journal=Serials Review|date=2009|volume=35|issue=4|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/00987913.2009.10765248?needAccess=true|accessdate=March 10, 2017}}</ref> by [[Michael Lerner (rabbi)|Michael Lerner]] and his then-wife Nan Fink Gefen. Since 2012, its publisher is [[Duke University Press]]. [[Beyt Tikkun]] [[Synagogue]], led by Rabbi Michael Lerner, is loosely affiliated with Tikkun magazine. It describes itself as a "[[Halakha|hallachic]] community bound by Jewish law".<ref name=Founding>{{cite web|url=http://www.beyttikkun.org/fmd/files/FoundingPerspective.pdf|format=PDF|title=Founding Perspective|work=Beyt Tikkun|accessdate=February 6, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20081002001335/http://beyttikkun.org/fmd/files/foundingperspective.pdf|archivedate=October 2, 2008|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Origin and meaning of the name== The magazine's title comes from mystical Hebrew concept ''[[Tikkun Olam|tikkun olam]]'' ({{lang-he|'''תיקון עולם'''}}; "healing or restoring the world"), emphasizing both humanity's and God's co-responsibility "to heal, repair and transform the world".
==Publisher== Initially, Nan Fink Gefen, at the time married to Lerner, devoted financial resources and served as a hands-on publisher until she left as their marriage ended in 1991.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} In 1997 a fellow 1960s-activist Danny Goldberg, a major music industry figure heavily involved in the [[ACLU]], became co-publisher with his father, Victor. During these years, prominent journalists such as [[Jack Newfield]] interviewed national and international leaders such as Mario Cuomo and Haiti's embattled President [[Aristide]] to bring more credibility to the growing influence of the magazine. From 2002 through 2011, Lerner's sister, [[Trish Vradenburg]], and her husband served as co-publishers.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}
==Editorial policy== Founded in 1986, the magazine's editorial policy was shaped by Nan Fink Gefen, Michael Lerner, and [[Peter Gabel]]. According to the founding editorial statement,<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.amazon.com/Tikkun-Heal-Repair-Transform-World/dp/0935933034/ref=sr_1_3/002-2929806-7815211?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1186208537&sr=8-3 |title=Tikkun 5 Year Anthology edited by Michael Lerner|publisher=Tikkun Books|year=1992}}</ref> political concerns of the 1960s civil rights, anti-war, and feminist movements and psychological studies of workers in the 1970s and 1980s were their most direct influences. Among authors who contributed to the magazine's interfaith character were the historian [[Christopher Lasch]], philosopher [[Cornel West]], and [[Harvey Cox]] of Harvard Divinity School.
Obliquely confronting more conservative American Jewish community's [[Commentary Magazine]], which caused some members of the Editorial Board, including [[Elie Wiesel]], to resign,{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} the magazine introduced itself with prominent ads placed in leading intellectual papers and journals declaring a new voice for the Jewish Left. Rabbi [[Abraham Joshua Heschel]]'s legacy of "prophetic" Jewish activism has been honored and analyzed from the first issue onward. Some writers who have contributed recently to the magazine include Michael Bader, [[Noam Chomsky]], [[Shaul Magid]] (a [[contributing editor]]), [[Benny Morris]], Or N. Rose (also a contributing editor), [[Edward Said]], [[Richard Silverstein]], [[Jim Wallis]], and [[Stephen Zunes]]. In every issue, it is stated that its articles "do not necessarily reflect ''Tikkun's'' position on any issue",<ref>{{cite news|title=Disclaimer|publisher=Tikkun|page=4}}</ref> and its editor, Rabbi Michael Lerner, has written that he "often consciously seeks to print articles with which he disagrees".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tikkun.org/rabbi_lerner/ask_the_rabbi_form|title=Ask the Rabbi|accessdate=February 7, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061231025743/http://www.tikkun.org/rabbi_lerner/ask_the_rabbi_form|archivedate=December 31, 2006|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==''Network of Spiritual Progressives''== In 2001 the magazine's interfaith activist community's website, the ''[[Network of Spiritual Progressives]]'', initially named differently, was established by founders that include ''Sister'' Joan Chittister, a [[Benedictine]] nun, and [[Cornel West]], a Princeton University professor of religion, in order to engage readers in broader activism and broaden the magazine's appeal to non-Jewish readers.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} Challenging the anti-religious and anti-spiritual biases within liberal culture and "replacing world domination with generosity" are among the ideas that are supported by the community.
==Controversy== ===Accusations of Anti-Semitism=== In 2005 [[Manfred Gerstenfeld]] cited an article published by ''Tikkun'' — [[Joel Kovel]]’s "On Left Anti-Semitism and the Special Status of Israel" (May/June 2003) — as one of two examples of "essays of Jewish authors using anti-Semitic arguments".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jcpa.org/phas/phas-30.htm |title=Jews against Israel |first=Manfred |last=Gerstenfeld |publisher=''Post-Holocaust and Anti-Semitism'' |date=March 1, 2005 |accessdate=February 7, 2007}}</ref> In his article, Kovel described Israel as a racist state that "automatically generates crimes against humanity and lacks the internal means of correcting them", adding that such a state "cannot have that legitimacy which gives it the right to exist".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zmag.org/content/showarticle.cfm?ItemID=3597|title=On Left anti-Semitism and the Special Status of Israel|author=Joel Kovel|work=Tikkun|date=May–June 2003|accessdate=February 7, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929130547/http://www.zmag.org/content/showarticle.cfm?ItemID=3597|archivedate=September 29, 2007|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In a 2006 column, [[Alan Dershowitz]] wrote that "''Tikkun'' is quickly becoming the most virulently anti-Israel screed ever published under Jewish auspices" and that "support for ''Tikkun'' is support for the enemies of Israel".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishsf.com/content/2-0-/module/displaystory/story_id/30647/edition_id/575/format/html/displaystory.html|title=The accusation: 'Moral pervert' hit piece shouldn’t have been spread|author=Alan Dershowitz|work=The Jewish News Weekly of Northern California|date=October 20, 2006|accessdate=February 7, 2007}}</ref> Dershowitz and his books have been the targets of criticism in the pages of ''Tikkun'' (for example: May/June 1997, September/October 1997, November/December 1997, January/February 1999).
===Improprieties regarding Letters to the editor=== In 1997 former ''Tikkun'' editors accused Lerner of publishing pseudonymous letters to the editor that he himself had written. While many of the letters were laudatory ("Your editorial stand on Iraq said publicly what many of us in the Israeli peace camp are feeling privately but dare not say."), a few were critical ("Have you gone off your rocker?"). Lerner admitted that he had written the letters but said his only mistake was not informing readers that the authors' names were pseudonyms.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jewishsf.com/content/2-0-/module/displaystory/story_id/5763/edition_id/107/formathtml/displaystory.html |title=Tikkun editor calls letter-writing policy 'a mistake' |date=March 21, 1997|author=Leslie Katz|work=Jewish News Weekly of Northern California|accessdate=September 30, 2010}}</ref>

{{thelema}} {{primary sources|date=January 2012}} '''True Will''' is a term found within the mystical system of [[Thelema]], a magical society founded in 1904 with [[Aleister Crowley]]'s writing of ''[[The Book of the Law]]''.<ref>Skinner, Stephen (ed). ''The Magical Diaries of Aleister Crowley: Tunisia 1923'', p. 79, n. 8. Weiser, 1996. {{ISBN|0-87728-856-9}}</ref><ref name=IAO131>IAO131. [https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/hdbq111/JoTS/JoTS1-1.pdf&date=2010-01-17+12:04:48 Thelema & Buddhism] in ''Journal of Thelemic Studies'', Vol. 1, No. 1, Autumn 2007, pp. 24</ref> It is defined either as a person's grand destiny in life or as a moment-to-moment path of action that operates in perfect harmony with Nature. True Will does not spring from conscious intent, but from the interplay between the deepest Self and the entire Universe. Thelemites in touch with their True Will are said to have eliminated or bypassed their false desires, conflicts, and habits, and accessed their connection with the divine. Theoretically, at this point, the Thelemite acts in alignment with Nature, just as a stream flows downhill, with neither resistance nor "lust of result". Crowley's ideas on the subject partly originated with the teachings of [[Eliphas Levi]], whose magical books emphasize the magician finding their magical identity – his or her 'true self', which Levi referred to as the "True Will".
== Thelema == Thelema roughly means "will" in [[Greek language|Greek]]. The phrase ''True Will'' does not appear in ''[[The Book of the Law]]'', the central sacred text of Thelema. Nevertheless, [[Aleister Crowley]]'s various commentaries on the Book routinely postulate that each individual has a unique and incommensurable True Will that determines his or her proper course in life. Crowley's invention appears to be an attempt to explain how some actions may be wrong (or "false") when "There is no law beyond Do what thou wilt".<ref>Liber AL III:60</ref> Actions that conform to True Will are thus considered to be correct, while willed actions that deviate from True Will may nevertheless be wrong. In ''The Book of the Law'' Crowley wrote "Do What Thou Wilt".
"DO WHAT THOU WILT" can often be misunderstood to mean "do what you want". When one says "do what thou wilt", this means that the origin of will directs the path. To understand and act upon one's True Will is a sort of "enlightenment" to Thelemites. The ultimate goal of a [[Thelema|Thelemite]] would be to understand and perform their True Will. True Will directs the individual towards destiny and forces them into the joy of accomplishing what they were meant to accomplish without "lust of result" (outside motivations).<ref>{{cite book|last=Crowley|first=Aleister|title=Liber AL vel Legis|year=1904|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/oto/engccxx.htm}}</ref>
== Writings == In Crowley's essay ''The Secret Conference'' (written under the pseudonym "Gerald Aumont", and prefaced to ''The Heart of the Master''), he suggests that a technique must be devised by which a child's True Will may be discovered at birth, or as early as possible in life, in order to permit the correct ordering of society.
In Crowley's ethical treatise [http://www.scarletwoman.org/docs/docs_duty.html ''Duty''], he identifies True Will with the Nature of the individual. This capitalized "Nature" may be compared with the "Perfect Nature" of earlier Gnostic systems, which was another term for the personal daimon or augoeides,{{Citation needed|date=June 2014}} usually referenced by Crowley as the [[Holy Guardian Angel]].
''The Message of the Master Therion'' ([http://www.scarletwoman.org/docs/docs_message.html Liber II]) is a document that attempts to delineate the doctrine of True Will. By reference to [http://www.hermetic.com/crowley/libers/lib913.html ''Liber Thisharb''], Liber II suggests a theory of metempsychosis, whereby the individual True Will is the resultant of a person's prior incarnations. But here as elsewhere, Crowley stops short of asserting objective validity for memories of past lives. He recommends developing "the magical memory" as a means to an end, and connecting the aspirant's abilities and remembered past with some purpose. By definition, the aspirant's True Will must fit the aspirant's nature.
In ''De Lege Libellum'' ([http://www.scarletwoman.org/docs/docs_lege.html Liber CL]), Crowley defines True Will as the will which "does not rest content with things partial and transitory, but...proceed[s] firmly to the End", and in the same passage he identifies that "end" as the destruction of oneself in love.
